A human lets the narrator contradict herself—“I’m not scared” followed two paragraphs later by a hand flying to her mouth. • Unique voice quirks: Unpolished slang misfires (“Whatever, this place is proper weird”), private jokes with a sibling who never appears, a running obsession with a random detail (say, how the chapel smell reminds her of her nana’s gingerbread). • Iterative, messy drafting: A human draft might linger on a scene for too long, delete it, then reintroduce it later. Fragments of ideas reappear in odd places, then get woven into the final draft in surprising ways. • Open-endedness: Humans often leave a question unanswered or a character’s future ambiguous—mirroring the uncertainty of real life. 1.2 Common LLM tropes and why they can feel flat • Safe, inoffensive plotting: LLMs shy away from real moral ambiguity, controversial details or messy emotional fallout. They aim for “broad acceptability,” which can wash out genuine conflict. • Package‐tying endings: A neat bow on every subplot. Real life and good fiction often leave loose threads or emotional aftershocks. • Formulaic structure: Inciting incident, midpoint, climax, resolution in strict order. That guarantees a smooth read but also predictability. • Overexplanatory narration: LLMs tend to fill in every motivation and every logical beat, rather than trusting the reader’s intuition or letting mystery linger. • Polished “voice” that lacks texture: No stumbles, awkward idioms or regional dialect slip-ups. Everyone sounds generic-author rather than a distinct, flawed teen. 2. Critique of Our Intention & Chapter Plan What’s slipping into formula? • Eight perfectly calibrated chapters, each hitting plot-beat landmarks. This feels more “outline for a writing class” than a messy first draft. • Two clear suspects (Mrs. Croft as red herring, Mr. Black as real culprit)—neat but perhaps predictable. A reader may sniff out the “new headmaster = danger” cliché. • Emoji escalation (3 drops → 5 drops → final 3 drops) is tidy but a little mechanical. A human writer might scatter more variation—an accidental “🩸🩸,” one missing emoji, or a deliberately garbled one. • Epilogue podcast cliffhanger (“🩸🩸🩸” again) neatly sets up a sequel. It’s satisfying, but perhaps too deliberate—a human might end on a more haunting image or emotional beat, not an obvious teaser. • Tone instructions (“dry, witty,” “sarcastic banter”) read like an LLM prompt rather than something emerging organically from character. Where the plan gives us good bones • Rooting the mystery in local history and a physical diary—tactile object with handwriting, smudges, editorial doodles, coffee rings. • The dark-comedy collision of mundane school life and genuine dread. • Themes of cover-ups in small communities and teenage solidarity—ripe for believable emotional stakes. 3. Brainstorming to Make It More Human 3.1 Infuse specific, idiosyncratic details • Bee’s survival ritual when she’s scared: a quick bowl of cereal (the crunchy bits snap louder at night), or an obsessive re-arranging of a scratchy poster on her dorm wall. • Dyl’s anxious tick: always tapping his phone, checking battery life, convinced any ghost app must have a “battery-kill” side-effect. • Mrs. Croft’s quirk: she always mispronounces Bee’s name (“BAY-ah”), or she insists the diary pages smell of “real Victorian ink.” • Mr. Black’s vanity: a tendency to rehang portraits of himself in awkward places, patching over them the next day in confusion. 3.2 Embed uneven pacing and emotional whiplash • Chapter 2 could detour into a late-night homework meltdown before the library clue. • Chapter 5’s break-in can be followed by a raw moment of real fear—Bee vomiting or dissolving in tears—before she steels herself, rather than immediately sprinting off. • A scene that doesn’t advance the mystery but deepens character, e.g., Bee crashing a boarding-school karaoke night. 3.3 Let some threads dangle • Reveal in Chapter 7 an inexplicable symbol that neither Croft nor Black can explain fully. It need not be solved by Chapter 8—leave it as an unsettling whisper in the final pages. • Maybe Tommy’s prank-crew buddy sends a final photo of Bee asleep at her desk, eyes wide open, as though watched. Never say who took it. 3.4 Play with structure • Open with a flash-forward of Bee collapsing under the chapel, clutching a bloody ring—but don’t immediately explain whose or why. Then rewind to Chapter 1. • Interleave diary excerpts in stylized, cramped transcript form that contrast with Bee’s breezy voice. 3.5 Embrace tonal shifts • Move from dry wit to sudden black humour: a cheery lunch-break banter cuts sharply to the clang of steel hinges on a crypt door. • Occasionally let Bee’s narration slip into genuine horror or lyricism, even if just for a sentence or two, to puncture the sarcasm. 3.6 Heighten moral ambiguity • When Black confesses, Bee might hesitate—does she leak it publicly or consider a private deal? Let her flirt with a compromise, reflecting teenage self-interest. • Show Mrs. Croft’s guilt over her gossip-fuelled obsession, not just her eccentricity. –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– By weaving in these messy, surprising, emotionally truthful elements—and by resisting the urge to wrap every thread in perfect logic—we push the piece off the “LLM outline” track and toward a richer, more human YA thriller with real texture, uncertainty, and heart.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention We’re crafting a darkly comic British YA thriller in eight ~1,000-word chapters that feels lived-in, messy, and unpredictable—like a teen’s half-remembered diary spliced with a true-crime podcast. Our lead, sixteen-year-old Bea “Bee” Harper, will narrate in a wry, self-deprecating tone shot through with genuine vulnerability: one minute she’s mocking the chapel’s creaking floors, the next she’s clutching her cereal bowl for comfort. Key choices: • Voice & Tone: A teenage narrator who stumbles over her own bravado—sarcastic but terrified, prone to late-night cereal binges and panicked phone‐battery checks. Black comedy emerges naturally out of mundane details (hostile chapel smells, vintage lacrosse trophies) colliding with growing dread. • Plot & Pacing: A rational mystery with “supernatural” frisson—every ghostly hint has a plausible human cause. We open with a flash‐forward to ratchet tension, then rewind. Diary excerpts—complete with smudged ink and doodles—are interleaved sparingly to deepen the puzzle. • Stakes & Themes: Secrets buried by small-town respectability versus the messy truth; teenage loyalty tested by fear; the potency of a single emoji text (“🩸🩸🩸”) in an always-online world. • What to avoid: Bullet-point neatness or overt “wrapping up.” We’ll leave one symbol undeciphered, one final text unexplained, and let emotional fallout linger beyond the last chapter. No cartoonish gore or fully supernatural scares—just claustrophobic tunnels, half-heard whispers, and the shock of real betrayal. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: Flash-Forward & First Drop – Open in media res: Bee collapsed beneath a kneeler in the chapel crypt, cradling a blood-stained ring, her torch flickering. A phone buzz: “🩸🩸🩸.” – Abrupt rewind to the previous night. Bee’s just moved into boarding house, snacking on cereal at 2 a.m. when the emoji text arrives. – She FaceTimes Dyl—he’s obsessively checking his battery (“If we lose power, we lose him”). They agree to treat it like a “mini true-crime doc.” – Bee spots a fresh smear of red paint on the chapel door’s latch: “Prank or prelude?” Chapter 2: The Diary in the Stacks – Bee skulks into the musty village library after school. Mrs. Croft greets her—mispronouncing “Bee-ah,” insisting the place reeks of “Victorian ink.” – Hidden in a dog-eared tome: a torn diary page. Smeared ink spells out “BLOODLETTER SOCIETY” below a curious spiral symbol. – Dyl arrives with his pocket-sized ghost-hunting app. They decode the “three drops” as “a warning.” – Bee has a meltdown over looming exams—spills coffee on the page. Dyl calms her with awkward pep talk. They vow to meet that night. Chapter 3: Fake Blood and Real Panic – At school, one locker is splattered with bright red paint. Viral videos buzz. Bee corners Tommy Grice, the lacrosse captain, who swears it’s guerrilla marketing for a horror festival. – He mentions a late-night chapel meeting of “history buffs.” Bee and Dyl stake out with a borrowed GoPro and Bee’s half-empty cereal box as dinner. – They catch Tommy and Mrs. Croft performing a tongue-in-cheek “Bloodletter” ceremony—giggling, not scaring. The symbol on their makeshift banner matches the diary. – As they slip away, Bee snatches a scrap of the banner: the spiral symbol under a fresh smear of what looks alarmingly like real blood. Chapter 4: Ledger of Secrets – Guided by a coded diary instruction (“Seek the heart that still bleeds”), Bee and Dyl break into Headmaster Black’s study after lights‐out. The old carpets smell of polish and dread. – In his bottom drawer: a ledger listing hush-money paid after a student’s accidental death in 1982. Next to it, a family photograph of Black cradling that missing girl’s sister. – Black nearly catches them. They hide in his filing cabinet; Bee’s panicked breaths echo. When he leaves, Dyl drops his phone—recording everything. – Outside, Bee’s phone buzzes: “🩸🩸🩸🩸🩸.” Five drops now. Dyl white-knuckles his phone. Chapter 5: Confronting Croft – Bee confronts Mrs. Croft in the library stacks. Croft’s voice quavers: she uncovered the diary decades ago and feared the dead girl’s “restless spirit.” – Croft produces the missing diary’s locket: a tiny, tarnished heart stamped with the spiral symbol. She pleads with Bee to drop the investigation. – Black appears in the doorway—a warning look, not murderous but very firm. Croft shushes him, eyes wet. Bee leaves with more questions than answers. Chapter 6: Beneath the Heart – A new clue—“beneath the heart, history lies”—leads Bee and Dyl to pry open a trapdoor under the chapel’s central kneeler (the literal “heart”). – Candle in hand, they descend into a cold brick tunnel lined with yellowed press clippings about that 1982 accident. Cobwebs tug at their clothes. Dyl almost trips a wire loop that clangs ominously. – At the tunnel’s end: a metal vault. Its lock is rusted; Bee’s heart hammers as she forces it open. Inside: the rest of the diary, a blood-smudged ring, and a scrap of Black’s ledger verifying hush money. – A distant echo of footsteps—time’s up. Chapter 7: Live Confession – Back in the chapel crypt, Black confronts them. He admits the girl’s death was accidental—he was protecting the school’s name, not the villagers’ grief. His voice cracks. – Bee hesitates: expose him and ruin the school? Or protect a flawed man? Dyl silently hits “record” on his streaming app. – Black lunges to grab the ring; in the scuffle, he slams into a pillar. The livestream roars to life. Paneled pews creak as hidden cameras pick everything up for a small but horrified online audience. – Black, face ashen, pleads mercy. Bee steps back, torn. Chapter 8: Aftermath & Unanswered Drops – Police and reporters swarm the chapel by dawn. Diary and ledger go to authorities; Mrs. Croft retreats to her cottage, clutching her locket. Tommy posts an awkward apology vlog. – Bee records the first episode of her “Midnight Emoji” podcast—her voice shaky, honest about her fear and guilt. – As she signs off, her phone buzzes one last time from an unknown number: “🩸🩸🩸.” Bee stares at the screen. Did she miss someone? Or is the spiral symbol still spinning, a promise that some truths never rest? – End on Bee’s hush—no neat resolution to the spiral’s origin, only the lingering dread of that final three-drop summons.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Bea “Bee” Harper Background & Personality • Sixteen, just transferred from Leeds to the small Cotswold boarding school when Mum took a night-nurse post at the local hospital. • True-crime junkie—memorised every podcast twist but panics when a real clue shows up. • Sarcastic coping mechanism hides a nerve-wreck: binge-eats cereal at 2 a.m., telling herself it’s “research fuel.” • Flaws: Overthinks every social move; convinced she’ll say the wrong thing and betray herself. Has mild agoraphobia from a childhood car crash (won’t ride in the back seat). Physicality & Mannerisms • Fine, ash-brown hair with a purple streak, perpetually mussed. Dark circles under green eyes. • Moves with slim, jittery energy—twitchy fingers, foot tapping when bored or terrified. • Dresses in thrift-shop layers: oversized hoodies, ripped jeans, battered trainers. Motives, Allegiances & Relationships • Needs to prove to herself (and silent Dad back home) that she can handle the unknown—mystery-solving is her ladder out of self-doubt. • Fiercely loyal to Dyl, her only friend; bristles if anyone dismisses him. • Distrustful of adults—already suspects Mrs. Croft and Mr. Black have secrets. Voice Samples Internal monologue: “Honestly, nothing says ‘welcome to your new life’ like an all-caps emoji murder warning at 2 a.m. Cereal, brace yourself.” Spoken line: “Sure, it’s ‘just paint.’ But last I checked, red paint doesn’t drip in perfect little tear-drops, does it?” # Dylan “Dyl” Khan Background & Personality • Seventeen, local student whose dad walked out last year. Lives with mum and a perpetually shedding hamster named Fibonacci. • Geeky, conspiracy-driven coder: built a rudimentary “ghost-app” in Python that he swears “works, mathematically.” • Overthought to paralysis—counts prime numbers when nervous, carries a multitool and spare batteries in his pockets. Physicality & Mannerisms • Shorter than average, wiry frame, always slouching in his oversized school uniform. • Thick-rimmed spectacles perpetually slipping down his nose. Bites his thumbnail when stressed. • Fiddles with phone settings every five minutes to “optimize ghost detection.” Motives, Allegiances & Relationships • Wrapped up in Bee’s confidence—helps her shine because he fears he’d vanish otherwise. • Desperate to prove his app (and himself) useful; wants recognition beyond being “that nervous kid.” • Soft spot for Mrs. Croft’s folklore stories, though he’s terrified of actually believing them. Voice Samples Internal monologue: “If X is guilty with probability .37, then why haven’t we checked the chapel drain? Must reserve battery for that.” Spoken line: “Bee, you sure this isn’t some marketing stunt for the spook-festival? Because I can’t afford a real ghost right now.” # Mrs. Winifred Croft Background & Personality • Mid-fifties, the village librarian and self-styled keeper of every dusty secret. Widowed ten years ago. • Eccentric collector of local ephemera—gaslight posters, tattered maps, and a shrine to the “missing girl” in a locked glass case. • Well-meaning but oversteps boundaries: blurts gossip, slips cryptic warnings, sprinkles peppermints among the reference copies. Physicality & Mannerisms • Petite, stooped shoulders, always in tweed skirts and lace-collared cardigans. Wire-rim glasses perched on a beaded chain. • Voice is a soft, tremulous whisper—until she gets excited, then she hisses. Rhythmic finger-tapping on marble counters. • Scent of dusty paper and spearmint follows her like a halo. Motives, Allegiances & Relationships • Feels the dead girl “speaks” to her through the diary; wants closure more than anyone. • Genuinely cares for Bee (sees a kindred curious spirit) but fears for her safety. • Uneasy truce with Mr. Black—she suspects him, but needs him to leave the library alone. Voice Samples Spoken line: “Oh, dearie, you mustn’t nose around here at midnight. The books start whispering then.” Internal monologue: “She’s far too brave for her own good. I should have hidden that diary better…” # Mr. Cedric Black Background & Personality • Early forties, newly appointed headmaster. Former barrister, driven and meticulously polite. • Presents as calm, paternal authority—broad-shouldered in charcoal suits, a tie always perfectly knot­ted. • Beneath the veneer: guilt-ridden secret-keeper. Believes protecting the school’s reputation justifies any lie. Physicality & Mannerisms • Tall, straight posture, glacial blue eyes that miss nothing. • Speaks in measured cadences, hands clasped behind his back. • Habitually re-positions framed certificates on his office walls. Motives, Allegiances & Relationships • Main goal: bury the 1982 accident and hush-money ledger to secure his career and the school’s standing. • Feels a reluctant fondness for Bee’s pluck, but sees her meddling as a threat he must neutralize. • Tense relationship with Mrs. Croft: mutual distrust, polite on the surface. Voice Samples Spoken line: “Ms. Harper, I appreciate your…enthusiasm. But some stones are best left unturned.” Internal monologue: “If she exposes the ledger, all my work here—poof. Reputation obliterated. Must keep her close.” # Tommy Grice Background & Personality • Seventeen, lacrosse team captain, scholarship kid who lives for adrenaline—good natured but desperate for attention. • Uses humour to deflect insecurity: cracks jokes, stages harmless pranks, craves approval. • Flaws: mask of confidence slips when alone; hates being ignored. Physicality & Mannerisms • Six-foot-two, athletic build, golden-blonde hair always artfully messy. • Moves with casual swagger, but jaw clenches when he’s nervous. • Twirls his lacrosse stick absent-mindedly, taps his phone to check for likes. Motives, Allegiances & Relationships • Wants to be the school’s “hero prankster”—in on the chapel stunt to boost his street cred. • Secret crush on Bee—buys her coffee, lingers awkwardly. • Friendly rivalry with Dyl, whom he sees as “brainiac sidekick.” Voice Samples Spoken line: “Look, Bee, it was just paint and silly theatrics. No one’s plotting your demise—promise.” Internal monologue: “Why do I keep stammering around her? Focus, Grice—get the scoop, not a date.”

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 1: Flash-Forward & First Drop I shouldn’t be here. Beneath the chapel’s stone kneeler, the air is damp and stinks of mildew—plus something coppery that makes my stomach flip. My palms are slick with sweat, my fingers curling around a ring so heavy it feels like lead. The torch in my other hand flickers, making the walls dance shadows like ancient churchyard demons. Then my phone buzzes in my pocket: 🩸🩸🩸. Three perfect red drops, glowing on the screen. I gasp. The ring slips against my palm. I catch it before it clatters into the dust, but blood seeps through the crack in its filigree band, staining my fingers. What kind of nightmare am I in? A slow tearing sound—someone approaching? I force myself to stay perfectly still, straining to hear more: the scrape of shoe rubber, a low voice. And then— **Rewind to seven hours earlier.** There I am, in my new boarding-house dorm, perched on the edge of an iron-framed single bed, socks on the radiator, clutching a half-empty cereal bowl. It’s two minutes past two in the morning, and I’m eating instant Granola Squares topped with cold milk. I tell myself it’s “research fuel.” It’s probably insomnia mixed with nerves, thanks to Mum’s new night-nurse rota at the hospital. I miss Dad, who’s still flat-sharing in Leeds and doesn’t understand midnight cereal binges. The walls are paper-thin. I can hear Louise in the next cubicle snoring like a deflating balloon. To stop myself from imagining horrors, I scroll through Dyl’s last text thread—endless timestamps, battery percentages, “Beta-testing ghost-app v.1.3.4.” I grin. obsessive much, Dyl? He’d code a spirit-detector app if it saved us from homework. I tap FaceTime. “Oi, Bee! Finally awake?” Dyl’s head pops into view, haloed by a desk lamp. He’s slouching at his cluttered desk: hamster wheel spinning, empty Red Bull cans, a tangle of charging cables. His face is pale under the glow, and his voice cracks every time he says a long word. Typical. “Got a midnight munch,” I whisper, lifting the cereal bowl like a chalice. “And you?” “My battery’s at thirty-two percent. Not great.” He holds up his phone like it’s a medical device. “And I’m monitoring your house feed. No paint-splattered corpses detected yet.” “Laugh it up.” I heel-tap the radiator until it hisses. Why isn’t it hot? “What if it is paint or–” I trail off as my own phone vibrates against the mattress. Light glints off the screen. My heart locks. I flip the phone up. Three sanguine drops: 🩸🩸🩸. The display’s dark background makes them look like real blood. “Dyl,” I croak. “I’ve got… this.” He leans closer. “Is that…?” I nod, nearly dropping the phone. “It’s from an unknown number. Just showed up.” Dyl’s nostrils flare. “Is it one of your True Crime Mystery pods pranking you?” “Not unless they’ve gone emoji-obsessed.” I swallow, pressing thumbprint. “We need a stake-out.” He sighs. “Stake-out at two-thirty? Bee, it’s chapel night-watch hour. I don’t want to lose you down a drain—or worse.” I shove my hair back, catch a glimpse of my reflection in the dark window. Shadows under my eyes spread like inkblots. “I need to know,” I say, voice brittle. Dyl rubs his thumbs together. “Fine. But if I die alone in the dark, I swear I’m haunting you.” I give him my best “bring-it” grin. “Deal.” We hang up. I tuck my phone under my pillow (battery priority), trumpet-myth style. I slip on sneakers and my purple-streaked hair falls into my eyes—classic me. I flip off the dorm light, leaving the hallway in bluish gloom. Outside, the moon rides high above slate roofs. The air is crisp enough to make me regret my thrift-store hoodie. My breath puffs out like smoke ghosts. The boarding-house doors squeak as I slip free. Ten minutes later, I’m slinking through the quads toward the old chapel, where gargoyles peer down in frozen disgust. My phone’s GPS flickers like it’s also spooked. When I round the corner, I nearly scream: red paint, still wet, drips in three little teardrops on the latch of the chapel’s heavy oak door. Perfect emoji form. I crouch, poking the drippy smear with my fingertip. It’s cold. Paint, for sure—but bright enough to pass for blood at a glance. I suck in air, adrenaline tangling my stomach. Footsteps. Dyl emerges from the shadows, gadget in hand. “I installed infrared last night,” he whispers, pointing a handheld device at the paint. The meter jumps—normal temperature. “Probably the paint stall at the village fair,” he adds, but his voice trembles. I stare at those three painted drops that match my phone’s text. “Or it’s a warning,” I say, heart slamming. “Someone out there is sending me a message.” He fumbles with his multitool, flicking a small LED light on and off. “Let’s get closer, see if there are—” A wind rattles the chapel windows. The painted drops hang in silence as if mocking us. I straighten, chest tight. “Next step: go inside,” I whisper. Dyl’s eyes flicker red beneath his glasses. “I was hoping you’d say ‘bake sale.’” “Screw the bake sale,” I chew out, trying to sound brave. “I’m doing this.” He exhales, then nods. “Your case, detective.” I press my hand to the cold oak door, the paint staining my finger bright crimson. One. Two. Three. And the night stretches ahead, full of silent prayers and pounding hearts.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] The chapter effectively establishes the darkly comic British YA thriller tone outlined in the writing plan. The author creates immediate tension with a flash-forward that places the protagonist, Bee, in a mysterious and threatening situation beneath the chapel, before rewinding to show how events began to unfold. The narrative voice captures Bee's character well - her self-deprecating humor, anxiety, and tendency to cope through midnight cereal binges all align with her character profile. The writing successfully conveys her as a true-crime enthusiast who suddenly finds herself in a real mystery. Her relationship with Dyl is established naturally through their interaction, showing their dynamic rather than explaining it. The prose generally avoids being overly purple, though there are occasional metaphors that feel slightly forced ("shadows under my eyes spread like inkblots"). The dialogue between Bee and Dyl feels authentic to teenage speech patterns, with their banter revealing character while advancing the plot. Dyl's obsession with battery percentages and his reluctant bravery match his profile well. The chapter follows the plan closely, hitting all the key points: the flash-forward with Bee in the chapel crypt, the rewind to her receiving the blood emoji text, her FaceTime with Dyl, and the discovery of red paint on the chapel door. The mystery is established effectively with the three blood drop emoji serving as the central motif. However, there are some weaknesses. The narrative occasionally tells rather than shows, particularly when describing emotions ("my heart locks"). Some of the scene transitions feel abrupt, especially the jump from the dorm conversation to being outside the chapel. The mystery setup, while intriguing, follows somewhat predictable beats for the genre. The writing creates a suitably atmospheric setting with the boarding school, chapel, and nighttime exploration, effectively building tension through environmental details. The chapter ends with an appropriate cliffhanger that propels the reader into wanting to know what happens next. Overall, this is a solid opening chapter that establishes character, setting, and central mystery while maintaining the darkly comic tone requested in the prompt. It successfully follows both the writing prompt and the chapter plan, though there's room for improvement in some technical aspects of the writing. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 2: The Diary in the Stacks The school bell rang its final claxon, but I lingered behind, heart racing like I’d just sprinted from a charging rhino. Everyone else spilled out into the quad, laughing about summer plans or texting their parents. I slung my bag over one shoulder and headed straight for the one building that felt less “welcoming” than the chapel at midnight: the village library. It sat—peppered with grimy mullioned windows and creeping ivy—next to the old post office. Rumour had it the librarian, Mrs. Winifred Croft, kept ghosts in her cardigan pockets. I pushed open the heavy door and was hit by that smell: old paper, mothballs, and something in the back stacks that reminded me of my nana’s gingerbread cookies, but musty and sour. Perfect. “Bee-ah, dear, back so soon?” Mrs. Croft’s voice flitted down the aisle. She materialised behind the reference desk, a pair of wire-rim glasses sliding down her nose. She sniffed the air theatrically. “You’ll catch a chill. This place reeks of Victorian ink.” She tapped her temple with a peppermint tin. “Mint helps the head.” I cleared my throat. “Right. Thanks, Mrs. Croft.” I dropped my bag on the floor. “I’m looking for local history—any books on the chapel archives?” She pressed her lips together, finger still on the tin’s lid. “Ah, the chapel. You youngsters and your midnight explorations.” She peered at me over the rims of her glasses. “Be careful, dear. Some doors should stay closed.” Her words prickled. I lifted my chin. “I know what I’m doing.” She sniffed again, then waddled away, muttering about “pesky teens.” My chest tightened. I hated feeling spied on. I needed a quiet spot, away from onlookers, so I tucked into a shadowy corner between two rows of Civil War pamphlets and gardening almanacs. I yanked out the library’s catalogue card—an ancient wooden box of index cards, its brass doorknob polished smooth by generations of fingertips. Under “C” for Chapel I found: “Chapels & Crypts of Cotswoldshire,” “Local Folklore & Superstitions,” and—buried under notebooks from fifteen years of book club minutes—a battered brown volume with no title on the spine. Perfect blind pick. Bringing it over to a reading table, I flipped the heavy cover: parchment so worn it threatened to crumble. I pried the book open and found, wedged between pages 46 and 47, a torn scrap of paper. My breath caught. Ink had bled, making the letters murky, but I could read enough: BLOODLETTER SOCIETY. Beneath it, someone had sketched a spiral symbol, the kind you might doodle if you were bored in chemistry class, but there was a little flourish that made it look ominous—like it was twisting into your skull. I tapped the page, trying not to smear the ink. I had exactly two tasks tonight: 1) figure out who sent me those emoji texts at 2 a.m., and 2) finish the essay on Victorian church architecture by Friday. Fantastic. My phone buzzed—Dyl’s caller ID, flashing “Ghost-App Beta.” I answered on speaker, cradling the diary scrap. “Bee, status report?” He sounded frantic, as though he’d been pacing in his room with Fibonacci the hamster glued to his shoulder. “I’m in the library,” I whispered, nodding to the near-empty aisle as if that would matter. “Check this out.” I held the page up to the camera. Dyl peered at it, squinting through his glasses. “BLOODLETTER SOCIETY,” he repeated, voice rising an octave. “That’s a local legend, right? Some secret club from the 1980s. Rumour says they met in the chapel crypt to—well, nobody knows exactly what they did.” I chewed my lip. “Sounds cheerful.” “Also—I’ve run the emoji through the app. Three drops usually mean ‘warning.’ Like, ‘back off,’ or ‘we know where you sleep.’” He paused. “Statistically, messengers are human ninety-nine point seven percent of the time, so I’m betting this isn’t a ghost prank.” His rational tone tickled my spine. I folded the scrap and tucked it into my hoodie pocket. “So it’s a human playing horror novelist—and it’s timed with my midnight wake-ups. Convenient, huh?” Dyl’s face filled the screen. “You have to be careful, Bee. Don’t touch anything else. And—” His voice cracked. “I’ve got the rest of the diary scanned. But I’d rather meet up and show you in person.” I nodded, even though he couldn’t see. “Let’s meet at my dorm in twenty.” I snapped the call off and stuffed the page inside my notebook. My palms felt clammy. My essay was screaming to be done, but this was bigger than a grade. I closed the anonymous volume and tried to jam it back exactly where I found it, but my elbow nudged a row of pamphlets. They rattled to the floor in a sad little avalanche. My face flamed. From the corner of my eye, I caught a twitching shadow—Mrs. Croft, peering from behind a shelf. “Oh, dear,” she whispered, eyes wide. “Keeping secrets already?” She hovered by the desk, voice too soft for any other reader to hear. “That book… it’s cursed, you know. People who tamper with it can’t rest easy.” I felt heat in my cheeks. “I—uh, I’m just curious.” “Curiosity is the oldest sin,” she said, then shuffled away. A peppermint slid from her pocket onto the floor. I bent to pick it up, rolling it between my fingers. “Curiosity killed many a mind.” She was enjoying herself. I shoved the pamphlets back, cereal crumbs crunching under my trainer. “Thanks for the warning,” I muttered. Two minutes later, I was racing outside, free breath glimmering in the cool afternoon. My bag felt heavier the second I thought about exams. I ducked into an empty bench by the front gate and sank down, pulling out a thermal mug of lukewarm coffee from my bag—exam junk-food stash courtesy of Tesco’s juiciest deal. I unscrewed the lid and took a gulp. It tasted like scorched wallpaper. I yanked out the diary scrap again and stared at the spiral. My hand trembled. One misstep here, one coffee spill… I traced the word “BLOODLETTER” with a fingertip, staining the edge of the paper. The coffee juggle proved a bad idea: hot sludge slopped over the side of the mug, dribbling onto the page. My stomach lurched. The ink blurred into a red smear that looked suspiciously like dripping blood. I ripped open a tissue and patted the page, pressing too hard. Ink ran, the spiral warped into something ugly and unrecognisable. “No, no, no!” I hissed, rocking the bench like it might roll back time. My phone rang again. Dyl. I clutched the mug, hot liquid burning my palm. “Bee? Are you okay?” he blurted as soon as I answered. I held up the soggy page. “Look at this.” My voice shook. “I—spilled coffee all over it. I’ve destroyed the clue.” He was silent for a second. Then, “It’s okay. Just breathe. I’ll be there in five. We’ll scan it, enhance the contrast, do a negative filter—whatever. You didn’t ruin it for real.” Tears pricked my eyes, partly from relief, partly because my plan was spiralling into mess. “Thanks.” I wiped my face. “I—I feel like a fraud. I can’t even keep a page intact.” “You’re fine,” Dyl said firmly. “You found it. That’s the hard part. I’ll sort the rest.” I let the corners of my mouth twitch upward. “You’re a lifesaver, battery-boy.” He laughed, that jittery sound I love. “Just keeping my circuits running.” I packed the coffee-and-ink blotch into a plastic sleeve, then shoved everything into my bag: notebook, rumpled essay draft, and the mysteriously bleeding page. My heart tapped out a staccato beat—fear, excitement, dread. That night, the library would close, rows of books locking up their centuries-old secrets. But the diary scrap was ours, smeared with coffee and foreboding. And I thought, not for the first time, that curiosity was a hell of a sin—and maybe, just maybe, one worth committing.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively establishes the darkly comic British YA tone while advancing the mystery introduced in the writing plan. The author creates a convincing teenage narrator in Bee, whose voice balances sarcasm with vulnerability as she investigates the mysterious text message. The chapter follows the planned structure closely, introducing the village library, Mrs. Croft, and the discovery of the diary page with the "BLOODLETTER SOCIETY" reference and spiral symbol. The relationship between Bee and Dyl is well-developed through their interactions, showing their complementary personalities and establishing their investigative partnership. The setting is richly atmospheric, with sensory details that create a suitably eerie mood: "old paper, mothballs, and something in the back stacks that reminded me of my nana's gingerbread cookies, but musty and sour." The library feels appropriately claustrophobic and mysterious, enhancing the story's tension. Mrs. Croft is particularly well-rendered, matching her character profile as an eccentric, boundary-crossing librarian who speaks in cryptic warnings. Her mannerisms—the peppermint tin, peering over glasses—create a vivid impression that's both amusing and slightly unsettling. The dialogue generally works well, particularly Mrs. Croft's cryptic statements and Dyl's tech-focused reassurances. However, some exchanges feel slightly forced, particularly when characters are explaining plot points. The chapter includes effective moments of humor (Bee's coffee "tasted like scorched wallpaper") and genuine anxiety (the panic when she spills coffee on the crucial clue). These emotional beats prevent the mystery from feeling too clinical or contrived. While the chapter largely avoids telling rather than showing, there are occasional instances where emotions are stated directly ("My chest tightened") rather than demonstrated through action or physical response. The prose occasionally reaches for metaphors that don't quite land naturally. The plot advances at an appropriate pace, introducing new elements of the mystery while leaving questions unanswered. The coffee-stained diary page creates a complication that feels organic rather than contrived, and sets up the next phase of investigation. Overall, this chapter successfully establishes the story's tone and central mystery while developing the key characters. It follows the chapter plan closely and remains faithful to the darkly comic British YA fiction prompt. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 3: Fake Blood and Real Panic First period French dragged on like melted tar. Madame Lefèvre droned about passé composé while I doodled spirals in the margin of my workbook, trying not to stare at my reflection in the window: hair a tousled purple-brown halo, uniform blazer shrugged off one shoulder. My phone buzzed—Group Chat blow-up. I peeked: a video of Locker 237, splattered with red paint that looked alarmingly like blood. Screams, emojis, and someone narrating in hushed tones: “Is this for real? #BloodyLocker #MidnightEmoji.” I shoved my notebook closed. Lefèvre’s soprano rose to a crescendo. I whispered, “Excuse me, Madame?” and she paused mid-lecture. I pointed to the video. “Have you seen this?” She blinked. “Zut, Bee, that’s…disturbing. But it’s paint. The art department’s hoping to promote the horror festival next week. They’re doing guerrilla marketing.” I frowned. “At ten this morning?” After school, the corridor was a tide of gossiping students. The press of lockers, the clang of heavy feet. I ducked under a banner advertising the school’s bicentennial gala and sprinted down the East Wing until I found 237. Sure enough, the locker door was smeared from top to bottom in glossy crimson. It looked fresh, like someone had blasted it with a fire extinguisher full of tomato sauce. I’d seen worse in Halloween haunts—but this felt too real. I zoomed in with my phone camera. A sticky glob dripped from the vent. My stomach lurched. I backed off, nearly colliding with Tommy Grice. He stood there in full lacrosse kit—muscle polos, knee socks—looking sheepish. “Bee,” he said, tossing me an awkward wave. “About the locker—honestly, it’s me.” I crossed my arms. “You?” I demanded. “Explain.” He shoved his hands into his pockets. “It’s for the horror fest, I swear. Me and some mates wanted to freak people out, get the buzz going. Totally harmless.” I raised an eyebrow. “Harmless? You’d post that at eight in the morning? People think someone’s hurt.” Tommy winced. “Point taken. We thought a morning scare would be killer marketing. It’s just red latex paint, Bee.” I pressed my palm to the locker—against my better instincts—and felt cool slime. Latex. “Explain the spiral symbol painted behind it, then. That shape’s not in the art brief.” His face went pale. He glanced at the floor. “Oh—right. That. That’s part of our…um, initiation thing. A bit of history buff theatrics. We found references to a midnight ‘Bloodletter Society’ in the archives.” My pulse jumped. “History buff theatrics?” He nodded, voice dropping. “Yeah. Some of our team—Mrs. Croft and I—we thought it’d be funny to reenact a ritual from the 1980s. Totally tongue-in-cheek.” He glanced over his shoulder, blinking. “Look, I can show you—tonight, chapel. History club meeting. No blood, I promise. Just…props.” I studied him. The sunlight glinted off his blonde hair; for a second, he looked almost earnest. Then his lips curled. “Want to see for yourself?” I clenched my jaw. “Fine. But I’m bringing backup.” *** At 10:15 p.m., I crouched in the hedges outside the chapel, armed with my GoPro—on loan from the media lab—and half a box of Raisin Bran for sustenance. Dyl hovered beside me, clutching his multitool and an extra battery for his phone. He looked about as thrilled as a spindle worm. “Why do we do this?” he hissed, breath fogging the cold air. I hissed back, “Because someone’s messing with me. Late-night emoji terror is one thing—paint-splattered lockers at dawn is next level.” I twisted the GoPro lens toward the chapel door. Three gargoyles glared down at us, stone claws ready to pounce. “Don’t…touch anything,” Dyl reminded me. Then, under his breath: “My ghost detector battery’s at twelve percent.” “Don’t die on me,” I muttered. We crept up the steps. I jammed the GoPro on top of the doorframe, flicking it to record. It blinked red: REC. I scanned the perimeter. No sign of security guards. We slipped inside. The interior smelled of church wax and dusty hymnals. Candle sconces lined the walls—unlit. Central pews in neat rows. The crypt entrance yawned open at the back, but that was for later. For now, we lurked behind the final pew, GoPro perched like a sentinel. Footsteps echoed in the nave. A hush fell. Two shapes emerged in the glow of an iPhone torch: Tommy Grice—trading his kit for a black hoodie—and Mrs. Croft, carrying a wicker basket full of weird props: a battered chalice, a smudged banner with the spiral symbol, and two small jars of red liquid. “I thought you’d never show,” Mrs. Croft whispered, voice quivering like a candle flame. “You have the banner?” Tommy held it up. Despite his assurances, the crimson stains on its folds gleamed too deeply for latex. Real blood? A perfunctory stage prop? My chest tightened. They arranged the banner on the altar: a simple white cloth embroidered with local school crests. Then Tommy knelt and said something under his breath, like a recited line. Mrs. Croft dipped her finger into one of the jars and traced the spiral symbol on the front of the chalice. She paused, inhaling. My brain sent me a flashing-alert: This is real. This is happening. Dyl nudged me. “We should intervene.” His voice sounded strangled. I shook my head. “Record first.” I edged forward, GoPro pointed. The lens caught their ritual: the arc of Mrs. Croft’s finger, the chalice ringed with red, Tommy’s closed eyes. Then Mrs. Croft popped a Peppermint from her cardigan to her mouth—my detail. I stifled a gasp. They clasped hands over the chalice and recited in unison: “By blood and vow, we honour the lost.” The words sounded hollow through the pews. They giggled, like naughty kids letting off fireworks in a church. They didn’t look conspiratorial—more like role-players. Tommy winked at Mrs. Croft and licked a smear of the red liquid off his finger. “Tastes like cherry cough syrup,” he murmured. His laugh echoed. My pulse flared. The banner’s spiral symbol looked identical to the one on my diary page. But this time, the smear beneath it was too deep, too dark. It clung to the canvas, like coagulated blood. I crouched lower, heart in my throat. Dyl’s grip tightened on my ankle. I took a breath. “We need that banner,” I whispered. Dyl’s eyes widened. “Are you insane? They’ll see us.” I peered through slats in the pew: Mrs. Croft had dropped her basket. The props lay on the stone floor. Tommy leaned in to pick something up. Timing—like threading a needle in zero gravity. I slipped forward, hand outstretched. The basket rattled. Mrs. Croft spun—eyes wild. “Stop!” Tommy’s head snapped up. The chalice toppled, clattering. The red liquid sloshed onto the altar steps. I jerked back, snatching the banner as I ran. Dyl fumbled with the GoPro but got footage of crimson drops flying from the torn fabric. We bolted down the aisle, polished pews rattling, slammed out the doors, and crashed into the night air. Branches whipped at my hoodie. Dyl nearly tripped over the chapel threshold but caught himself. I staggered to the hedges, collapsing into the prickles, clutching the banner. The spiral symbol stared back at me, under a glistening smear too dark to be paint. Dyl vaulted over the low wall and landed beside me, eyes shining. “You got it?” he panted. I held up the banner. Fresh drops dripped from the spiral. “We have our symbol.” He tapped the GoPro. “We caught them in the act. Proof.” I pressed the fabric to my chest. My heart pounded like a warning bell. Mrs. Croft’s betrayal sting was colder than the night air. Tommy’s prankster grin haunted me. And above it all, the spiral symbol—more tangled than ever—throbbed in my hands. I gasped for breath. “Next stop: Mr. Black’s office,” I whispered. Dyl nodded, voice small and fierce. “Five drops next time, Bee. Five drops means danger.” I inhaled the crisp air, pressing the banner to my heart. The mystery deepened. The next chapter loomed: ledger secrets and midnight break-ins. And with every scarlet drip, the world grew more dangerous—exactly how I suspected, exactly how I feared.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully establishes the darkly comic British YA tone while advancing the mystery plot. The author creates a convincing teenage narrator in Bee, whose voice balances sarcasm with genuine fear. The chapter follows the planned structure, showing the discovery of the fake blood locker, confrontation with Tommy, and culminating in the chapel stakeout where they witness the "Bloodletter" ceremony. The strongest elements are the atmospheric details that ground the story in a specific setting. The chapel with its "church wax and dusty hymnals," Mrs. Croft popping a peppermint during a supposedly serious ritual, and Bee's Raisin Bran as stakeout sustenance all contribute to the darkly comic tone. These small touches make the world feel lived-in and authentic. Character consistency is generally strong. Bee's internal monologue maintains her established voice, showing both her sarcasm ("Why do we do this?") and her genuine anxiety. Dyl's nervousness about battery percentages and his reluctance align with his character profile. Tommy's characterization as attention-seeking but ultimately harmless comes through in his sheepish explanation and his winking during the ritual. The dialogue generally works, though occasionally feels a bit stilted. Lines like "Explain the spiral symbol painted behind it, then" sound more formal than a typical teenager's speech. Some exchanges, particularly between Bee and Tommy, feel slightly mechanical rather than organic. The plot advances logically, building tension through the discovery of the locker, Tommy's suspicious explanation, and the nighttime chapel investigation. The chapter ends with a clear hook toward the next plot point (Mr. Black's office), maintaining momentum. There are moments where the writing tells rather than shows, particularly regarding emotional states. For instance, "My pulse flared" and "My chest tightened" are somewhat generic physical descriptions that don't fully convey the specific quality of Bee's fear. Similarly, "My brain sent me a flashing-alert: This is real" directly states what could be conveyed through more specific sensory details. The chapter occasionally relies on familiar tropes of YA mystery (hiding behind pews, dramatic escapes), but generally avoids becoming too predictable by including unexpected elements like Mrs. Croft's involvement and the ambiguity about whether the blood is real or fake. Overall, this is a solid chapter that successfully balances the darkly comic tone with genuine tension, while advancing the plot and maintaining consistent characterization. The writing is generally strong, with occasional weaknesses in dialogue and emotional description. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 4: Ledger of Secrets “The heart still bleeds.” The diary’s final line of text was cramped in spidery handwriting, the spiral symbol smudged across the bottom. I chewed on my lower lip, staring at the words beneath the harsh yellow glow of Dyl’s flashlight. We crouched behind a mossy buttress outside the chapel, the night pressing in like damp wool. “Heart…” Dyl murmured, wiping away cobwebs. He tapped his ghost-app’s screen. “I checked local architecture. The chapel’s kneeler is shaped like a heart—right beneath the altar. But it’s just stone.” I pressed a gloved hand to the cold buttress. “Maybe metaphorical. What else in this building is heart-shaped?” I swallowed. “The school crest. The crest’s on Black’s office door.” Dyl’s eyes glinted. “Headmaster’s office it is, then.” He held up a thin crowbar he’d jury-rigged from a library bookend. “Keyless entry, hopefully.” I pressed a finger to my lips. “Shh. Movement.” A slow scrape in the distance: the caretaker’s late-night walk. We flattened against the buttress until his flashlight beam passed. My heart drummed in my ears. When the footsteps receded, Dyl jabbed me. “Now.” We slipped through the narrow side door—left propped open for late monks or tea deliveries—and skirted the main chapel floorboards, careful not to creak. The corridor beyond smelled of polished wood and old disinfectant. I tugged Dyl’s sleeve, pointing to the dim glow under the headmaster’s door: a tiny keyhole light flickering as though breathing. I produced my borrowed hairpin and kneeled. My fingers trembled so badly the pin rattled against the lock. Above us, the old floorboards groaned. I bit my lip. With a soft click, the lock turned. I froze, chest fluttering. Dyl peeked—no one. My palms were drenched. I eased the door open a crack. Inside, Headmaster Black’s office was immaculate: a polished mahogany desk, leather-bound volumes neatly aligned, framed student portraits on the walls. On his desk lay a silver pen set and—too conveniently—an unlocked drawer. I exchanged a look with Dyl: gamble taken. We edged in, shoes whispering against the carpet. Dyl circled left, examining the portraits. Most were laurels and smiling boarders—until he paused at one: a sepia-toned photo of a little girl in an old-fashioned school uniform, clutching a doll, her tear-streaked sister—Mr. Black, maybe ten years old—holding her close. The caption read: “Celia Morton & Brother, 1982.” I stepped forward, breath catching. “That’s her. The aunt we read about. The missing girl died… he was her guardian?” My voice caught. Dyl’s index finger hovered over the photo. “He paid hush-money to the Morton family.” He pointed toward the desk, where a ledger peeked out. “Look.” I crossed and slid open the bottom drawer. Inside lay a yellowed leather ledger, its cover cracked and loose. I flipped it open. My stomach twisted. On crisp columns of ink were names, dates, and sums: “1982, Morton family, £5,000. 1982, Church Trustees, £2,000. 1983, Mr. Aldridge, £1,000…”—a meticulous log of hush payments. My breath hitched. Black had covered up an accident, suppressed it page after page, payment after payment, to protect the school’s reputation. The red-tipped ink of one entry looked oddly fresh: “BLOODLETTER DIARY – £500.” Beneath it, a date scrawled in shaky handwriting: October 31, 1982. Halloween. Dyl’s hand quivered on the desk. “Do you have this?” he whispered. I froze. My phone camera—still in my pocket—was set to record. I pressed record. A tiny red dot blinked: REC. A shadow crossed the frosted glass of the office door. Black’s silhouette filled the frame. My pulse thundered. He unlocked the door and stepped in, shoes clicking. Dyl dropped a stack of envelopes. They fluttered like startled birds. I prayed he wouldn’t freeze. Black’s shoulders stiffened. He muttered something under his breath—anger? Fear? He strode to the desk, eyes narrowing at the open drawer. I backed away, heart pounding so loud I was certain he could hear it. He bent to close the drawer as I barely dared to breathe. I felt Dyl’s hand squeeze my arm. His lip was white. The moment hung in the air like a guillotine. Then Black straightened, as though satisfied by what he saw—or perhaps pondering damage control. He turned away from the desk and adjusted a framed certificate on the wall, smoothing a speck of dust with precise fingers. The guest record for that night lay untouched on the desk. Time tiptoed. Black groaned softly, rubbed his temple, then turned toward the door. His gaze flicked to the spilled envelopes on the floor and—briefly—to the soft glow of my phone screen peeking from my pocket. His jaw clenched, and I pressed record even harder, thumb shaking. He opened the door and stepped out, closing it with an unsettling quiet. I exhaled like a deflated balloon, crouching until the glass winked off the corridor light. The offices beyond were empty. We had minutes at most. I whispered, “We got it. We got it all.” Dyl let out a shaky laugh. “I recorded the whole thing.” He held up his phone, screen flashing red. “Proof.” “We need to leave, now.” I shut the drawer, dropped the ledger and photo back in place, then stood. The office looked undisturbed—no sign of our break-in except that faint jumble on the carpet. We slipped out, closing the door with a soft click. I turned the corridor corner, and my phone vibrated in my hand. I flipped it open. Five sanguine drops glowed on the screen: 🩸🩸🩸🩸🩸. My chest seared. Dyl’s jaw dropped. “Five drops,” he whispered. “That means—” I swallowed hard, thumb hovering over the emergency call screen. “Danger. Imminent danger.” He swallowed. “We have the ledger, the photo, the confession—but if he knows we’ve seen it, he’ll come after us.” I pressed the phone to my ear. “We need safety. And strategy.” Dyl’s voice cracked: “And maybe a new battery?” He pointed at my phone. “At this rate, my app’s going to die.” I managed a shaky grin. “After this, we both need sleep.” I placed my phone in my pocket, heart still pounding. “But first… we survive the night.” We hurried down the silent corridor, the ledger’s weight lighter than my dread—but heavy enough to promise that the heart of our mystery still bled, and someone was sending clearer warnings than any paint or satin banner. Five drops, carved in glowing red: the clock was ticking.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively builds tension through a high-stakes break-in to the headmaster's office, revealing crucial plot information while maintaining the darkly comic British YA tone established in the writing plan. The narrative successfully balances Bee's internal anxiety with external danger, creating a compelling scene that advances both character development and plot. The prose captures Bee's nervous teenage voice well, with lines like "The night pressing in like damp wool" and "My heart drummed in my ears" effectively conveying her anxiety without overplaying it. The author skillfully builds atmosphere through sensory details—the smell of "polished wood and old disinfectant," the "soft click" of the lock turning, and the visual of envelopes fluttering "like startled birds." Character consistency is strong. Bee maintains her true-crime junkie persona while displaying realistic fear. Dyl's nervousness and technical focus (his ghost app, jury-rigged crowbar) align perfectly with his character profile. The brief appearance of Headmaster Black captures his meticulous nature and underlying tension. The plot follows the chapter plan closely, hitting all key points: the coded diary instruction, breaking into Black's office, discovering the ledger with hush money records, nearly getting caught, and ending with the escalated emoji threat. The revelation about Black's connection to the missing girl adds emotional complexity to what could have been a one-dimensional villain. Dialogue is sparse but effective, serving to advance the plot and reveal character rather than merely filling space. The exchanges between Bee and Dyl feel natural for nervous teenagers in a high-pressure situation. There are a few minor weaknesses. Some descriptions verge on telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining Black's motivations. A few metaphors feel slightly forced ("deflated balloon"). The chapter could benefit from more distinctive British vernacular to strengthen the setting. Overall, this is a strong chapter that successfully builds tension while revealing crucial plot information. It maintains the darkly comic tone while delivering genuine suspense, and the characters remain true to their established profiles. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 5: Confronting Croft I slept maybe two hours before my brain exploded into panic. Every time I closed my eyes I saw Black’s ledger entries dancing in greenish gloom: “Morton family, £5,000. Bloodletter Diary, £500.” My mouth tasted like sawdust, and my phone lay dead beside me—five drops pulsing on the screen, mocking me. Dyl arrived at dawn, scuffing his trainers in the hallway, hair sticking up in alarmed tufts. His eyes were bloodshot, voice gravelly. “Bee, we—maybe we should call this off.” He clutched his multitool like a talisman. “I can’t handle five drops. That’s…someone getting ready to hurt us.” I rummaged in my bag for a teabag—black tea, no sugar—then gave up and tore open an instant coffee sachet. The library could wait, but Croft wouldn’t tell me the rest of her story without an audience. I poured hot water into the chipped mug and set off. The library arrived silent, windows dark. I tugged the door open, the ancient bell jingling like a distant alarm. Shelves huddled in foggy morning light. The place smelled of dust and secrets. Dyl hovered by the reference desk, blinking at his phone’s empty battery icon. “Morning,” I mumbled, wrapping my hands around my coffee. I tried to swallow, but grit from the mug scoured my tongue. “I need to see Mrs. Croft.” He followed close, gaunt and nervous. “Think she’ll help?” “Only one way to find out.” I spotted Mrs. Croft at her usual perch, bent over a pile of newspapers on the reading table. She wore a burgundy cardigan—peppermint tin in the pocket—and her wire-rim glasses were fogged by the morning chill. “Mrs. Croft,” I called. My voice cracked. She looked up, startled, as though woken from a dream. “Bee-ah!” She rose, knocking over a stack of The Cotswold Gazette. Pages fluttered like moths. She extended a hand, tremulous. “You mustn’t have come back so soon.” I edged forward. “You have to tell me everything you know about the diary—and the spiral symbol.” Her eyes darted to the windows, then back to me. “I—” She swallowed hard, weaving her fingers through the air. “I found the diary decades ago. It belonged to Celia Morton. I’ve kept it hidden, hoping that—well, I hoped she’d find peace.” My pulse skittered. “You have it?” Croft nodded, voice a thread. “In my cottage. I wore this.” She reached into her cardigan pocket and produced an odd little locket: heart-shaped, tarnished silver, stamped with that godforsaken spiral. My lungs froze. “I kept it, thinking it might help me channel her spirit.” I sucked in air. “Channel her spirit?” She pressed the locket to her lips. The hinge squeaked as she opened it, revealing a scrap of yellowed paper—tiny, cramped writing. “This is the last entry.” She trembled. “I believed, foolishly, that the girl would…talk to me.” Dyl cleared his throat. “Mrs. Croft, with all due respect, spirits aside, someone is using the diary to scare Bee—and paint lockers.” Her hands shook so badly the locket rattled. “I never meant harm. I was only…curious. But once the spiral appeared on that banner, I feared. I begged Mr. Black to stop the history club’s prank—they took my warning as encouragement.” She dabbed at her eyes with a lace handkerchief. “They thought it was all theatrics. I thought I could protect them by controlling knowledge.” I folded my arms, coffee mug slipping down my sleeve. “Knowledge you weren’t about to share.” She nodded, voice breaking. “I was afraid someone would misuse it. But now…” She gestured at my stained uniform. “You’ve gone too far. You’re in real danger, Bee-ah. Five drops means someone is close to violence.” I swallowed. The taste of fear was bitter. “I need the diary entries.” Croft’s gaze flicked downward. “I…destroyed most of them after the accident. I hoped forgetting would make the village sleep again.” My stomach lurched. “So you burned pages?” Her knuckles went white. “Some. Others I hid. But the rest…” She closed her eyes. “I lost the key.” I clenched my jaw. “Then you’ve been lying.” She flinched. “I was protecting everyone—the school, the trustees, myself. And perhaps protecting you—for you are curious, like me.” The hush felt thick as soup. I fought to calm my racing thoughts. If she had the locket and a fragment of diary, she could answer the spiral’s origin. But if she burned pages… I had nothing. From the hallway came a heavy step—resonant, deliberate. Mrs. Croft’s head snapped to the door. My gut plummeted. Mr. Black filled the doorway, his charcoal suit crisp, eyes narrow slits. He surveyed the widening circle of newspapers at Croft’s feet, then flicked his gaze to us. “Winifred, what’s happening here?” Croft sank back, her voice a stuttered whisper: “I…just talking with Bee-ah about local archives.” He advanced, lips set. “The library’s closed for the morning. Ms. Harper, I value your curiosity, but some stones are better left unturned.” He fixed me with a look—an odd mix of stern pity and veiled threat. I clenched my mug tighter, coffee sloshing over the side. “Mr. Black, we know about the ledger. We know about Celia Morton.” His jaw tightened. “You know nothing.” He turned to Croft. “Mrs. Croft—please see to these messes.” He nodded to the scattered newspapers. Then he left, footsteps echoing down the corridor. Croft sank into a chair, hand over her mouth. “He knows something’s wrong.” Her voice trembled. “I’m sorry.” I slid forward, lowering myself to the chair opposite her. “You saw me spill coffee on that diary scrap. I ruined it. Then you showed me the locket fragment. But you burned the rest. Why?” She stared at her shaking hands. “They begged me to keep silent. Trustees threatened to sue, funds would be pulled from the church. I believed secrets preserved peace. I was wrong. I see that now.” Dyl sniffed. “So what now?” Croft glanced at me, blue eyes haunted. “You must stop digging. Return what you have. End this.” I drew a slow breath. Blood hammered in my ears. “I can’t.” She closed her eyes, tears slipping. “Then I can’t help you.” I rose, luggage of disappointment grounding me. Dyl’s hand found my shoulder. “We’ll figure it out.” Mrs. Croft looked up, fresh resolve flickering through her fear. “There is…one other place. A vault beneath the chapel floor. I found its key years ago. But I was too scared to descend alone.” My pulse thundered. Beneath the chapel…vault… That was where the rest of the diary might lie, intact. The crypt. The spiral’s lair. Dyl’s eyes shone. “Let’s go tonight.” Croft clenched her locket, head bowed. “If you do this—promise me you’ll be careful. Five drops in means risk of real harm.” I nodded, voice steeled. “We’ll be careful.” She thrust the tiny locket into my palm. “Take this. It’s all that remains of her words.” I closed my hand around it, cool metal pressing against my skin. One spiral-stamped heart. One fragment of a voice long silent. And the promise of deeper secrets below. We left the library with more questions than answers—louder doubts, fresher fears—and a thin silver locket swinging in my pocket, beating like a badly wired alarm. Tonight, we’d descend into darkness. And whatever lay beneath would finally meet the light.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively advances the mystery while developing the characters and their relationships. The author has created a tense confrontation with Mrs. Croft that reveals crucial information while maintaining suspense about what lies beneath the chapel. The chapter follows the planned confrontation with Mrs. Croft, though with some modifications. The revelation of the locket and Mrs. Croft's admission of destroying diary pages adds complexity to her character. Mr. Black's appearance creates tension, though his role is somewhat subdued compared to the plan. The prose effectively captures Bee's voice - anxious, determined, and slightly sarcastic. Lines like "My mouth tasted like sawdust" and "The library arrived silent" establish her perspective well. The author skillfully conveys Bee's emotional state through physical sensations and observations. Character consistency is strong. Bee maintains her determined yet anxious demeanor, Dyl his nervous tech-dependency, Mrs. Croft her tremulous eccentricity, and Mr. Black his authoritative menace. The dialogue generally rings true to their established voices, though occasionally becomes slightly generic. The setting details are atmospheric - "Shelves huddled in foggy morning light" and "The place smelled of dust and secrets" create a vivid sense of place. However, some descriptions could be more specific to avoid cliché. The pacing works well, building tension through the confrontation and ending with a clear setup for the next chapter. The revelation about the vault beneath the chapel creates anticipation for what's to come. Some weaknesses include occasional telling rather than showing ("The taste of fear was bitter"), a few instances of purple prose ("luggage of disappointment grounding me"), and dialogue that sometimes feels slightly forced. The chapter could also benefit from more specific sensory details unique to this particular library. Overall, this is a solid chapter that advances the plot while maintaining the darkly comic British YA tone established in the prompt. It successfully builds tension and leaves the reader wanting to know what happens next. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 6: Beneath the Heart The locket lay on my desk, its tiny hinge worn thin. I flipped it open again: inside, a scrap of yellowed paper—fragmentary script so cramped it might’ve been written with a pin. Dyl peered over my shoulder, eyes lit by the desk lamp. “Read it again,” he whispered. I traced the words: “Beneath the heart, history lies.” Beneath the heart… the chapel kneeler was carved in a heart shape, right under the altar. My pulse thundered. “That’s it,” I said. “We go down there.” Dyl’s grip on his phone tightened until his knuckles blanched. “My battery’s at five percent. And it’s cold. And I’m pretty sure my ghost-app is going to croak.” I grabbed my backpack, shoving in a battered brass candlestick, a half-used box of kitchen matches, and a cheap LED lantern I’d nicked from the media lab. “I’ve got spare cereal bars. You won’t starve.” I snapped his phone into my portable charger. “Plug in.” He shot me a look that mixed gratitude and dread. “You know this is basically trespassing…right?” I slammed my notebook shut. “Yes. And if we wait for an invitation, we’ll be waiting forever.” Night fell swift and silent. The chapel’s stone gargoyles loomed as we crept up the worn flagstones. I shoved the side door open—the one we’d wedged earlier—and we slipped inside. The foyer smelled of wax and old sermons; the nave was emptied of pews. We skirted the marble altar until we reached the heart-shaped kneeler. It sat there in ghostly moonlight—a single carved block of limestone, its rounded top looking suspiciously like an anatomical heart if you squinted. Beneath it, a faint seam etched a rectangle into the stone floor: a trapdoor. I knelt, heart hammering, and ran my gloved fingers along the seam. Moss and candlewax flecks clung to the edge. I pressed the brass candlestick’s slender handle into the gap and pried. The door groaned—a low, complaining rumble like an angry beast. “Nice,” Dyl murmured, shining his LED in. “Can we leave now?” I gritted my teeth and forced the hatch upward. Cold air whooshed out, smelling of damp earth and stale secrets. Below lay a ladder of iron rungs, slick with rust. I slid the hatch back so it rested on top of the kneeler, then struck a match. The tiny flame trembled as I lit the candle, propping it in the candlestick. I climbed down first, boots thudding on the bottom rung. Dyl followed, swearing under his breath as he bumped knees against the ladder. The hatch clattered shut above us. I pressed my shoulder against it to muffle the sound, then shone my lantern around. We stood in a narrow tunnel of red bricks, damp mortar squelching underfoot. The walls were plastered with yellowed press clippings—arched headlines screaming about “TRAGIC DEATH AT CHAPEL” and photographs of a pale girl in a 1980s uniform, a bloodstain on her sleeve. Beneath each clipping, someone had scribbled the spiral symbol in pencil. My breath caught. “They pinned evidence down here,” I whispered, stepping close. Fingertips skimmed newspaper edges. One clipping crackled as I lifted it: mention of Celia Morton, age fourteen, killed by a falling beam during renovations. The coroner’s report said accident, but the locals always whispered cover-up. Dyl crouched beside me, his glasses fogged. “Look at those loops,” he pointed. Across the tunnel floor, thin wires crisscrossed like tripwires—part of some clicker alarm. His ghost-app screen glowed at 3% before flickering off. “Great.” He bent to lift a loop. His elbow nudged the wire and—clang!—a metal bracket kicked against the wall, sending an echoing ring after us. I yelped and clamped my hand over his mouth. Dyl froze, breath caught. We stood motionless as the tunnel swallowed the reverberation. I could almost feel footsteps above—no, my own heartbeat. “Sorry,” he mouthed, wide-eyed. I put a finger to my lips. “Shh.” My pulse pounded so loud I thought it might crack the bricks. We waited, breath suspended, until only the drip of water filled the hush. “This way,” I whispered, pointing down the tunnel where it bent left. We shuffled forward, candle flame bobbing, lantern light slicing through damp gloom. At the bend stood a squat metal door set into the bricks. A heavy padlock secured it. I closed the distance, heart whirling. “This has to be it.” Dyl produced his multitool and leaned in as I fitted the hairpin into the lock’s keyhole. My fingers shook so badly the pin rattled. I bit my lip, then twisted. The lock clicked—freedom. My heart screeched. I yanked it open. Inside lay a small vault: shelves of dusty leather-bound diaries, their pages yellowed but intact. On top, a silver ring—matching the one I’d fumbled in the chapel crypt—its spiral engraving filled with dried blood. Beside it, a folded scrap of Black’s ledger: an entry I hadn’t seen before, dated just after Celia’s death: “Morton hush payment completed.” I crouched, panting. Reverently, I lifted the top diary. Its cover read “Celia’s Journal” in careful cursive. I pried it open: the first entry was dated June 1982, smudged ink on slick pages. My stomach cramped. Dyl leaned in with his phone camera. “Breathe,” he whispered. “Document everything.” I flipped pages with trembling fingers: entries about Celia’s lonely days, her fear that the beams were unsafe, her vow to expose “the truth my brother won’t.” The spiral doodles sprawled across margins, smudged by tears. On the final page, a smear of fresh-looking red, as though someone pressed their palm there. I closed the journal, voice thick. “She knew. She tried to warn them.” Dyl scooped up the ledger scrap and the ring, tucking the ring into his coat pocket and the paper into his backpack. I slid Celia’s diary under my arm. The candle trembled in its holder. Shadows danced across rows of tomblike journals—ghosts of voices silenced, now spilling their words at last. I swallowed, mouth dry. “We need to get back. Now.” The tunnel fell silent—too silent. Then, from above, a muffled thud: concrete against wood. My chest tightened. Footsteps. “Time’s up,” I whispered. Dyl snagged my sleeve. “That’s fast.” His voice quavered. I shoved the candle into my pocket and switched on the LED lantern. It sputtered, but glowed. “Climb.” I jumped to the ladder and hoisted the diary. Dyl followed, lugging the backpack heavy with evidence. The trapdoor scraped as we pushed it open and clambered out into the chill of the chapel floor. I slammed the hatch shut behind us, pressing shoulder to stone until it clicked. We twisted the brass candlestick to brace it upright, then bolted for the side door. The moon had dipped behind a cloud; the quad lay in deeper shadows. We sprinted across the grass, hearts hammering in synchrony. Behind us, the chapel door creaked—no shout, no curse, just the slow swing of stone on hinge. I didn’t look back. Not until the library windows were in sight—that sanctuary of dusty books and peppermint tins. Only when I hit the threshold did I allow myself to breathe, chalky air flooding my lungs. Dyl sank against the wall, breathing hard. “We made it.” I steadied the diary in my arms, eyes shining. “We did. And now we have her words.” He met my gaze, voice soft: “Next step: make him talk.” I nodded, heart still drumming—but steadier now. Beneath the heart had given us history, but upstairs, someone held the final key. And we were ready to turn it.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully captures the atmosphere of a darkly comic British YA thriller, though with some notable strengths and weaknesses. The author has created a tense, atmospheric exploration beneath the chapel that advances the mystery while maintaining the established tone. The chapter follows the planned structure well, with Bee and Dyl discovering the trapdoor beneath the heart-shaped kneeler and exploring the tunnel filled with evidence about Celia's death. The physical details of the setting are vivid and atmospheric—the damp tunnel, yellowed press clippings, and the vault containing the crucial evidence all contribute to a sense of claustrophobic discovery. Character consistency is generally strong. Bee maintains her determined, slightly reckless nature while Dyl remains anxious but loyal, constantly checking his battery and worrying about consequences. Their dynamic feels authentic to their established profiles, with Bee pushing forward and Dyl providing both technical support and nervous caution. However, the dialogue occasionally feels functional rather than distinctive. While there are some good lines that capture the characters' personalities ("I've got spare cereal bars. You won't starve."), other exchanges serve primarily to move the plot forward without showcasing the unique voices established in the character profiles. Dyl's dialogue, in particular, sometimes lacks the mathematical, analytical quality described in his profile. The prose is generally effective, with some nice sensory details like "The chapel's stone gargoyles loomed" and "The foyer smelled of wax and old sermons." However, there are moments where the writing becomes slightly overwrought ("My heart screeched") or relies on telling rather than showing emotional states ("My stomach cramped"). The pacing works well, building tension as they discover evidence and then creating urgency when they hear footsteps above. The chapter ends with an effective transition to the next phase of the story, setting up the confrontation with Black. While the chapter follows the plan and advances the plot competently, it doesn't fully capitalize on opportunities for the darkly comic tone promised in the prompt. The humor is subdued, with only a few moments of levity amid the tension. Additionally, some potentially rich emotional moments—like Bee's reaction to reading Celia's journal—feel somewhat rushed and underdeveloped. Overall, this is a solid chapter that advances the mystery and maintains the established atmosphere, though it could benefit from more distinctive dialogue and deeper emotional resonance. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Characters Consistent with Profile: 15 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 7: Live Confession I balanced on the edge of the chapel crypt entrance, candle in one hand, Celia’s leather-bound diary in the other. The narrow stone tunnel yawned behind me like a mouth hungry for secrets. Dyl huddled beside me, phone in record mode—his streaming app primed on “Live.” Twenty viewers already tuned in, none of whom knew what hell we were about to unleash. “Are you sure about this?” Dyl’s voice trembled. A sputter of static echoed across the digital feed. “If he finds us—” “He’ll confess,” I whispered, heart hammering. “He has no choice.” I checked my pocket for the blood-stained ring. It was heavy and cold against my palm. Somehow, it felt like an invitation—and a noose. We slipped out of the tunnel’s mouth and into the gloom of the crypt. The air was cold enough to see our breath. Candlelight trembled over rows of stone slabs and carved nameplates. I shivered.
