This was the place Celia’s spirit—if ghosts existed—would haunt. “Channeling her,” Dyl muttered, as though comforting the ether. He tapped his phone screen. “Live feed’s stable. No traceable IP. You want to do the honors?” I clenched the ring. “Let’s call him.” My phone’s screen lit up: Headmaster Black—ringing. I pressed ‘Answer’ and brought it to my ear. “Black here.” His clipped voice echoed oddly in the crypt’s stillness. “Meet me beneath the altar,” I said, tone cold. “Midnight. Alone.” My heart drummed. “Or your secrets die with you.” He hesitated. I could almost hear his pulse through the line. “Harper… this is—” “Midnight.” I hung up and dropped into a crouch beside a broken stone kneeler. Dyl swallowed. “He’ll come.” “Until then, we wait.” I flicked off the candle and slipped the ring into my hoodie pocket. Complete darkness swallowed us. Thirty minutes later, my ears pricked: footsteps above. Echoing steps on flagstones. I pressed flat against the cold slab, diary clutched to my chest. Dyl crouched beside me, face ashen in the phone’s glow. A shape appeared at the tunnel mouth—Mr. Black, suit impeccable even under cloak of night. He carried a small torch, face pale, lips pressed into a thin line. “You set this up?” he demanded. His voice echoed near the altar. “What is this, a trap?” I stepped forward into his torchlight, hands raised in a mock peace gesture. “You owe us the truth, Mr. Black. Celia Morton died in 1982. You paid hush-money to her family. We want your confession.” He blinked. “Ms. Harper—if you’ve broken in here—” I cut him off, dropping my hands and pulling the diary from my bag. “Read this. Every page. You’ll see she knew the beam was loose. She tried to warn you. You blamed her curiosity for the accident.” He took a step closer, gaze flickering to the diary’s embossed title. Candlelight—or torchlight—traced the dust on his shoulders. “You don’t understand.” I shook my head. “I do. You silenced her to save reputations.” Black’s jaw clenched. He held up a hand. “If you post this online—” “You’re on live.” Dyl’s voice boomed from the phone’s speaker. “You can deny it, or you can tell us yourself.” Black’s eyes flicked to the tiny red dot blinking on Dyl’s screen. Then he inhaled, voice low. “Fine.” He dropped his shoulders, the suit jacket sagging. “I protected the school. I covered up an accident. The beams were old, sure, but she was never supposed to be in that attic. She snuck up there with a friend, and the wood gave way.” His voice cracked. “I paid her family, promised them anonymity. Trustees threatened to cut funding if it went public. I thought I was doing the right thing—protecting hundreds of kids from scandal.” My mouth went dry. Dyl’s phone camera panned to capture Black’s face in full. Viewers ticked up: 48… 72… “You could have warned her,” I said, voice trembling. “You could have shut down the renovations until it was safe.” Black’s blue eyes glistened. “That girl was like a sister to me. I failed her.” He glanced at my phone. “But you dragging this into the light—” “Go on,” I urged. He swallowed. The torchlight flickered across the carved ribs of a nearby sarcophagus, turning them into ghostly fingers. Black closed his eyes. “I—I told them the incident was minor; she had fallen but recovered. I transferred funds to the Morton estate. They signed non-disclosure agreements. I thought that was closure.” His voice broke, echoing against stone. “But my guilt… it never left me. Every day I walked those halls, I saw her face.” Dyl’s voice cut through the hush: “And you’re confessing that now, in front of God and the internet?” Black nodded, face ashen. “Yes.” A heavy silence fell. The only sound was a distant drip of water—like a tear from the crypt itself. I pressed my phone to my ear, switching from record to livestream. Comments flew by: “OMG he’s crying” “this is huge” “Harper 4 headmaster.” I swallowed. This was victory—but at what cost? Black pointed to the diary. “Return her words to her family. Publish it. Let the world see.” I nodded, voice steady. “We will.” He took a faltering step toward me, then hesitated. “I… thank you—for making me face it.” His gaze drifted to a carved stone heart on the far wall. “But be careful. Some truths should come out slowly.” I opened my mouth—but Dyl cut in. “I’m streaming all of this to my friends, your colleagues, every local news channel. You can’t walk this back.” Black’s shoulders sagged. He turned and walked toward the tunnel entrance, torchlight lowering until he vanished into darkness. Dyl tap-shushed the viewers. “That’s it,” he said. “We got it.” I lowered my phone, legs wobbling. The diary felt like an anchor in my arms—heavy with real human pain, not just puzzle pieces. Dyl shut off the stream. “Six hundred and fifty views,” he breathed. “And they’re sharing like wildfire.” I exhaled, relief and dread knotted in my chest. “We did it.” His eyes met mine, fierce. “What now?” I traced the spiral engraving on the ring in my pocket. “Now… we let the dust settle.” I closed the diary gently, as though tucking Celia’s voice safely away. My phone buzzed—news alerts blinking with headlines: “Headmaster’s Tears—Live Confession from Chapel Crypt.” I swallowed, voice low. “Justice is messy.” Dyl nodded. “But at least it’s real.” We crept out of the crypt, leaving torchlight behind. The world above would never look at chapel stones—or midnight emojis—the same way again.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter presents a climactic confrontation between the teenage protagonists and Headmaster Black in the atmospheric setting of a chapel crypt. The execution shows both strengths and weaknesses in its attempt to deliver the darkly comic British YA thriller promised in the writing plan. The chapter succeeds in creating a tense atmosphere with its crypt setting, candlelight, and the confrontation with authority. The basic plot points from the chapter plan are followed: Black is confronted, he makes a confession that's captured on livestream, and there's a moral ambiguity to the resolution. The chapter maintains the established characters and their dynamics, with Bee taking the lead and Dyl providing technical support. However, the execution falls short in several areas. The dialogue often feels stilted and overly formal for teenagers ("You owe us the truth, Mr. Black"). The confrontation lacks the promised complexity - Black confesses too easily without much resistance, making the climax feel anticlimactic. The "scuffle" mentioned in the plan where "Black lunges to grab the ring" is entirely absent, removing a key moment of physical tension. The narration relies heavily on telling rather than showing emotional states ("My heart drummed," "relief and dread knotted in my chest"). The promised "wry, self-deprecating tone" of Bee's narration is largely missing, with few instances of the dark humor that should characterize the piece. The cereal-eating quirk mentioned in her character profile appears nowhere. The chapter also fails to deliver on the "messy" and "unpredictable" qualities promised in the writing plan. The confrontation unfolds in a straightforward manner with minimal complications or surprises. Black's confession feels rehearsed rather than reluctantly extracted, and his emotional breakdown isn't convincingly portrayed. The writing occasionally slips into purple prose ("The narrow stone tunnel yawned behind me like a mouth hungry for secrets") and contains some awkward metaphors ("The diary felt like an anchor in my arms"). These moments distract from the narrative rather than enhancing it. While the chapter maintains coherence and follows the basic plot outline, it lacks the emotional depth, distinctive voice, and narrative complexity promised in the writing plan. The characters feel like vessels for plot advancement rather than the complex, quirky individuals described in their profiles. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 10 Emotionally Engaging: 9 Compelling Plot: 11 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 13 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 10 Purple Prose: 9 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11 Characters Consistent with Profile: 12 Followed Chapter Plan: 13 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 14

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 8: Aftermath & Unanswered Drops Dawn broke pale and slack across the quad. I hadn’t slept—couldn’t—ever since the livestream hit six hundred views overnight. Now, clusters of police officers in rain-slick jackets swarmed the chapel steps. Reporters jostled for angles, lenses bobbing like curious fish. Crime-Scene tape cordoned off the entrance; florescent markers glinted where investigators collected samples. I stood behind the yellow ribbon, chewing the inside of my cheek, clutching a half-cold travel mug of coffee that tasted like regret. Dyl hovered beside me, sneakers scuffed, pale-eyed. We watched as Headmaster Black—now escorted by two constables—stepped through the tape, shoulders slumped, face pinched. “Game over?” Dyl whispered. “Sort of,” I said, shifting my weight. The barrel of guilt still rode heavy in my stomach. “But it feels like the beginning of a very long day.” He blinked, gaze sharp. “Mrs. Croft?” I turned toward the library’s side door. There she was, shoulders hunched beneath a threadbare coat, carrying that peppermint tin like a protective talisman. She paused in the archway, eyes flicking to me. I waved, forcing a tight smile. She gave a small nod, then slipped inside, the door closing with a resentful thunk. I exhaled. “She’ll be okay.” “Tommy Grice?” Dyl tilted his head toward a TV crew interviewing a lacrosse-team kid with purple streaks smeared down his face. Beside him, Tommy looked harried, cheeks red. He cleared his throat. “Look, I—I’m sorry,” Tommy stammered into the mic. “That locker paint stunt was my idea. I didn’t think it’d go this far. I never meant real fear—definitely didn’t know about the crypt or the diary. I was wrong. And I’m sorry, Bee.” He angled to the side, mouth tight. “I’m taking a break from team stuff.” I caught his eye. He offered a half-embarrassed wave, shoulders rounded. I gave him a subtle nod. Some friendships survive confessions; others just limp along afterward. Dyl draped an arm over my shoulders. “Good riddance, bad sportsmanship?” he joked. I let out a shaky laugh. “Yeah. Let’s hope the rest goes smoother.” We edged between reporters and curious boarders, heading for the chapel’s side entrance—the one unimpeded by tape. Inside, the altar was stripped clean; the crypt hatch locked. The candle we’d used was long melted. Police notes lay on a folding table: a black evidence bag, Celia’s diary wrapped in plastic, the ledger scrap sealed in an envelope stamped “Exhibit A.” I reached out and brushed the edge of the plastic. The diary’s spine—once a secret world—was now public domain. My heart lifted and sank all at once. “C’mon,” Dyl said. He led me down the aisle, past overturned hymnals and vacant pews. “Time to record.” We climbed the steps to the empty choir loft—our makeshift podcast studio. The high wooden seats rattled with every footstep. Sunlight splayed through stained glass, painting the dust motes in shards of sapphire and ruby. Perfect visuals for grim storytelling. I pulled my phone from my pocket. It still showed “🩸🩸🩸🩸🩸” frozen on the screen from the night I broke into Black’s office. I stared at it, thumb hovering over “Messages.” Too late now to return to “just a puzzle.” “Ready?” Dyl said, flipping the phone to “Record.” He passed me a cheap USB mic lifted from the media lab. I cleared my throat—one of my least favorite habits. “Hello, everyone,” I began, voice catching. “This is Bee Harper, and welcome to Episode One of the Midnight Emoji Podcast.” I swallowed. “I’m recording from the…former choir loft of St. Aldwyn’s Chapel, where last night—” I paused, heart pounding in my throat. Reporters’ cameras could capture this, but no one here was watching. This was just us: me and Dyl, and anyone brave enough to tune in. “Last night,” I repeated, voice steadier, “we uncovered the truth behind the emoji texts. A missing girl, a secret society, and the man I once trusted most—our headmaster.” Dyl tapped my shoulder encouragingly. I pressed on: “Today, Celia Morton’s diary is in safe hands—the authorities. The hush-money ledger is part of an ongoing investigation. Mrs. Croft, the librarian who once held the key to every secret, is recovering at home. And yes—that was Tommy Grice you saw apologizing for a paint stunt gone wrong.” I let out a breath I didn’t even know I was holding. “But this is just the beginning. Because some secrets”—I tapped the spiral ring on my finger—“don’t stay buried, no matter how many stones you leave unturned.” I lifted the ring in front of the phone lens. “And though we’ve exposed one truth, another message just arrived.” I held the phone up close: a new text from an unknown number. Three crimson drops: 🩸🩸🩸. My breath caught so hard I worried I’d knock the mic over. Dyl’s eyes widened. I stared at the screen, mind racing. “This is the part where I say ‘stay tuned.’ Except…I don’t know what comes next. All I can promise is we’ll keep digging, keep asking the hard questions, and yes, keep a backup battery on hand.” I tapped “End Recording.” The red light blinked out. Dyl exhaled behind me. “Not bad for Episode One.” I slipped the ring back into my pocket. “Not bad at all,” I murmured—though my gut twisted at that final three-drop summon. Was it a fail-safe? A prank from a gossip-hungry friend? Or had we woken something that refused to rest? Below us, the chapel bells tolled the hour, their deep tones vibrating through the rafters. I listened, half expecting a whisper in the echo: another drop, another warning. Dyl nudged me, voice soft. “Let’s call it a day.” I clipped the microphone back into my bag, tucking in my scribbled notes. “Yeah. Let’s get out of rabbit-hole reporting and find some breakfast.” We climbed down, stepping carefully over the silent pews. Outside, the morning sun had burned off the mist, leaving the world crisp and unneeding. Students trooped in, curious eyes on the yellow tape. Reporters clustered like guttersnipe birds. I touched Dyl’s arm. “Ready for cereal at the common room?” He grinned, shoulders loosening. “And hot chocolate for me.” I smiled back. “Deal.” We walked toward the boarding house, the chapel receding behind us. The air smelled like wet grass and fresh starts. Maybe a promise of peace—or at least a momentary reprieve from enigmas and haunted symbols. But in my pocket, the phone rested, screen dark until I unlocked it. Three little drops glowed: 🩸🩸🩸. I stared at them, heartbeat thudding in my ears. Did I miss someone? Or is the spiral’s whisper still spinning? I slipped the phone into my pocket. “After breakfast,” I said. “We’ll figure it out.” Dyl punched my shoulder. “Always an adventure, right?” “Always,” I agreed—though a glimmer of dread flickered beneath the promise. Three drops: the oldest warning in the book. And I wasn’t ready to turn off my phone again.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter effectively wraps up the main mystery while leaving enough threads dangling to create intrigue. The author has crafted a satisfying conclusion to the immediate plot (the exposure of Headmaster Black and the truth about the 1982 accident) while maintaining tension with the new mysterious text message. The chapter excels at capturing Bee's voice, which remains consistent with her character profile. Her internal monologue feels authentic to a sixteen-year-old - slightly dramatic but self-aware, with phrases like "coffee that tasted like regret" that fit her character without becoming overwrought. The narrative maintains the darkly comic British YA tone established in the prompt and writing plan. The aftermath scenes are handled with appropriate weight. The police presence, reporters, and crime scene tape create a realistic picture of what would happen after such revelations. The brief interactions with Tommy and Mrs. Croft efficiently show the fallout without belaboring these secondary character arcs. The podcast recording scene serves multiple purposes - it provides a natural way to summarize events for readers while showing Bee's growth as she takes ownership of the story. This scene also cleverly introduces the new mystery text, setting up potential future adventures without undermining the resolution of the current plot. However, there are some weaknesses. The dialogue occasionally feels functional rather than distinctive - Dyl's lines like "Game over?" and "Mrs. Croft?" are serviceable but don't showcase his character's unique voice as established in his profile. Some of the emotional beats could be more deeply explored - Bee's feelings about Black's downfall and her role in it are mentioned ("The barrel of guilt still rode heavy in my stomach") but not fully developed. The prose occasionally slips into telling rather than showing, particularly when describing characters' emotional states: "I let out a shaky laugh" and "My heart lifted and sank all at once" tell us Bee's feelings rather than letting us experience them through more visceral details. The chapter follows the plan quite faithfully, hitting all the major plot points outlined: the police and reporters at the chapel, Mrs. Croft retreating to her cottage, Tommy posting an apology (though it's delivered in person rather than as a vlog), Bee recording her podcast, and the final mysterious text message. The ending successfully creates the lingering dread mentioned in the plan, with Bee uncertain about the meaning of the final three-drop summons. Overall, this is a strong conclusion that balances resolution with mystery, maintaining the established tone and character voice while setting up potential future adventures. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This YA mystery story follows Bee Harper and her friend Dyl as they investigate mysterious blood emoji texts and uncover a decades-old tragedy at their boarding school. The piece successfully captures the darkly comic British YA tone requested in the prompt, blending teenage drama with gothic mystery elements. The story's strongest aspects are its consistent voice and the gradual unfolding of the mystery. Bee's first-person narration maintains a distinctly British teenage voice throughout all eight chapters, with appropriate slang and attitude. The plot builds logically from the initial emoji text to the discovery of Celia Morton's death and the subsequent cover-up. Character-wise, Bee is well-developed as a curious, determined protagonist with a penchant for midnight cereal and true crime podcasts. Dyl serves as a loyal tech-savvy sidekick whose ghost-detection app and constant battery concerns provide comic relief. Secondary characters like Mrs. Croft and Headmaster Black have sufficient depth to be interesting, though they sometimes veer toward stock characters (the mysterious librarian, the guilty authority figure). The pacing is generally effective, with each chapter advancing the plot while ending on mini-cliffhangers. However, the middle chapters (4-6) occasionally drag with repetitive investigative scenes. The final chapters rush somewhat to wrap up the mystery while still leaving threads dangling for a potential sequel. The world-building creates a convincing British boarding school setting with atmospheric details: the chapel with gargoyles, the musty library, the damp crypt. These gothic elements enhance the mystery without overwhelming the contemporary setting. Dialogue is a mixed bag. While it often captures teenage speech patterns well, some exchanges feel stilted or overly expository. Characters sometimes speak in ways that serve the plot rather than reflecting natural conversation. The prose occasionally suffers from purple tendencies, particularly in descriptive passages where metaphors pile up ("The air is crisp enough to make me regret my thrift-store hoodie. My breath puffs out like smoke ghosts."). Some metaphors feel forced ("My pulse thundered. The banner's spiral symbol looked identical to the one on my diary page."). The story sometimes tells rather than shows emotional states ("My chest tightened. I hated feeling spied on.") instead of demonstrating these feelings through action or physiological response. This weakens some potentially impactful moments. While the central mystery is engaging, certain plot elements are predictable for the genre: the guilty headmaster, the librarian with secrets, the red herring prankster. The "Bloodletter Society" concept feels underdeveloped, serving mainly as a plot device rather than a fully realized element. The story remains faithful to the prompt, expanding the initial blood emoji text into a full mystery with appropriate darkness and humor for the YA audience. The ending balances resolution with new questions, maintaining the darkly comic tone throughout. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 15 Nuanced Characters: 14 Pacing: 14 World Building: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 9 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 70.2/100
+ Space Western — Cargo Unknown (Chapter Avg: 77.9 | Final: 73.7)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something&#x27;s... moving in that crate we picked up. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming Characters - The Captain • Veteran frontier pilot, pragmatic but haunted by past losses • Moral center—torn between duty, profit, and compassion - The First Mate • Loyal ex-marshal with a strict personal code • Expert in firearms; uneasy around anything unhuman - The Engineer • Young, brilliant tech-savvy tinkerer who believes science can explain anything • Secretly fascinated by alien life - The Cargo Specialist • Shady, mercenary-type hired to secure and deliver the crate • Knows more about the contents than they claim - The Medic • Empathetic, quick-thinking, suspicious of corporate motives behind the crate • May sympathize with whatever’s inside - The Creature (or “Whatever’s in the Crate”) • Unknown life-form—could be parasite, symbiote, or sentient juvenile species • Shapeshifting or telepathic potential; ambiguous threat vs. victim Plot Ideas / Story Beats 1. “The Pickup” • Deceptive deal on a lawless outpost world; crew acquires sealed, vibrating crate • Subtle hints of danger—equipment interference, low growls 2. “First Incidents” • Small anomalies: tools misplaced, strange noises in vents, crew dreams • Tension builds among crew: fear vs. curiosity 3. “Crate Break” • Crate latch fails; the life-form escapes into the ship’s lower decks • Isolated sections go dark; crew splits into search parties 4. “Revelation” • Crew encounters creature: it appears frightened, maybe intelligent • Questions: kill it as a threat, study it, or turn a quick profit? 5. “Division” • First Mate and Cargo Specialist push to exterminate; Engineer and Medic want to contain/study • Captain must decide whose side to take 6. “Corporate Conspiracy” • Ghost message from the shipyard or employer: crate’s contents are military-grade bio-weapon • Adds stakes: blowing the whistle means corporate wrath 7. “Climax—Showdown in the Hold” • Creature corners itself or crew; frantic firefight or tense negotiation • Life-or-death choice: sacrifice creature or crew, risk contamination 8. “Aftermath” • Resolution on the character arcs: who wins, who loses • Ambiguous hook: remnants of the creature survive, hinting at future trouble Tone & Style - Gritty Space Western: dusty frontier stations, neon-lit cantinas, starship spurs and plasma pistols - Suspenseful, gradually ramping to horror elements - Moral ambiguity: no clear “good” or “evil” sides - Quartering of chapters: each ends on a cliff or moral dilemma Pacing Over 8 Chapters (~1,000 words each) 1. Setup and foreshadowing; establish world & stakes 2. Quiet escalation; small scares, character reactions 3. Major turning point—the crate opens 4. Creature reveal; shift from mystery to confrontation 5. Conflict deepens; crew fractures 6. Backstory and corporate pressure heighten stakes 7. High-tension climax 8. Aftermath and lingering unease # Reflection – Variety vs. Focus: We brainstormed parasite, symbiote, sentient juvenile—too many creature types can diffuse impact. Better to pick one that serves both horror and moral themes. – Western Flavor: Leaning into frontier-meets-space adds grit and visual flair. Gunslinger tactics against alien biology can underscore genre mash-up. – Character Dynamics: The Engineer vs. First Mate split fuels internal conflict. Adding a shady Cargo Specialist gives an outside wildcard. That triangle plus the Captain’s moral tug will drive emotional stakes. – Corporate Angle: Introducing a bio-weapon backstory in mid-story adds urgency and a wider conspiracy, but risks overcomplexity. We must weave that in without derailing the creature’s personal arc. – Pacing: Eight chapters at 1,000 words means each beat must be lean—establish tone quickly, escalate steadily, minimal filler. – Cliffhangers: Each chapter should end with either a physical scare or a moral decision to propel the reader forward. – Tone Balance: Must balance tension/horror with Western grit. Too much gore could overshadow character drama; too little suspense could feel tame. In the actual plan, I’ll aim for a single, ambiguous creature—something both vulnerable and dangerous—to anchor the moral conflict. The cargo conspiracy will surface in chapter 5 or 6, so early chapters can focus on suspense and crew dynamics. This should give a tight, compelling arc that honors the prompt: “Captain, something’s… moving in that crate.”
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention This story will be a lean, suspense-driven Space Western focused on moral ambiguity and building tension around an unknown life-form. Tone and Style • Gritty frontier setting with neon cantinas, dusty outposts, and starship gunplay. • Suspense and slow horror: we show small, eerie incidents before revealing the creature. • “Show, don’t tell”: minimal info-dump; character reactions and dialogue carry worldbuilding. • Each chapter ends on a cliff or dilemma to propel momentum. Character & Creature • Captain: seasoned veteran, torn between profit, duty, and compassion. • First Mate: ex-marshal, decisive but fearful of the alien unknown. • Engineer & Medic: idealists, want to study or help the creature. • Cargo Specialist: mercenary with hidden corporate ties; catalyst for conspiracy reveal. • Creature: a single juvenile, sentient symbiote—vulnerable yet potentially dangerous; can mimic voices in its environment. Plot Choices • Focus on a lone, ambiguous creature rather than multiple monster types. • Introduce corporate/bio-weapon subplot starting mid-story to heighten stakes without overwhelming early suspense. • Keep internal crew conflict sharp: kill vs. contain vs. profit. • Avoid heavy legal or political exposition—hints of a larger conspiracy suffice. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: “The Pickup” • Setting: dusty frontier port Karwin’s Rest—neon lights, rusted hulls. • Introduce Captain, First Mate, Engineer, Medic, Cargo Specialist. • Crate acquisition from a jittery dealer; strange hums and vibrations. • Cliff: late-night alarms—crate rattles violently. Chapter 2: “First Incidents” • Ship under way: engine glitch, nav-computers flicker when crate is nearby. • Tools go missing, voices echo in vents—crew tensions rise. • Engineer installs scanners; Medic dreams of whispered warnings. • Cliff: Medic peers inside crate’s porthole—sees a pale, tentacled shape. Chapter 3: “Breakout” • Crate latch gives way during turbulence; creature escapes into lower decks. • Lights flicker; First Mate arms up, crew splits to search. • A maintenance drone is mauled; one crew minorly wounded. • Cliff: Captain hears someone mimicking his voice over the comms. Chapter 4: “First Contact” • Crew traps the creature in a maintenance bay; it cowers, then lashes out telepathically. • It mimics a dead crew member’s voice, begging for mercy. • Engineer argues it’s scared, Medic wants to help; First Mate demands execution. • Cliff: Cargo Specialist locks bay doors remotely, voice over intercom: “That life-form is property.” Chapter 5: “Lines Drawn” • Reveal: the crate is marked for military R&D; corporate override code enacts quarantine-by-extermination. • Crew splits: Captain agonizes, haunted by past losses; First Mate & Specialist prepare weapons; Engineer & Medic rig a humane trap. • Tension boils as trust erodes. • Cliff: Corporate beacon pings—a task force is en route. Chapter 6: “Sympathy and Siege” • Medic feeds the creature; it responds with limited telepathy, revealing fear and intelligence. • First Mate leads assault on the lab; firefight erupts, casualties on both sides. • Captain confronts Specialist over corporate lies. • Cliff: ship’s comms seal off—task force has locked them in. Chapter 7: “Hold or Hazard” • Final showdown in the cargo hold amid flickering lights. Creature tries to access navigation controls. • Captain must choose: stand with crew to kill the creature, release it to escape, or betray both to save himself. • Sacrifices made: who lives, who dies. • Cliff: Captain fires—unclear who survives. Chapter 8: “Aftermath” • Dawn breaks as ship limps away. Survivors tally losses. • Captain consoles the wounded; Engineer and Medic bury the dead and debate the creature’s fate. • Last beat: a faint hum from the sealed cargo bay—something moves. • Final line hints the symbiote endures, and the moral cost haunts them all.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# How a Human Writer Might Approach This Piece 1. Personal Connection & Emotional Stakes • A human often mines personal experience or emotional truth—loss, fear of the unknown, moral regret—to ground the sci-fi tropes. • They might remember a time they felt claustrophobic or discovered something unsettling in a garage or attic, then transpose that sensory memory into a starship hold. 2. Finding a Unique Voice • Rather than a generic “Space Western” pastiche, a human will latch onto one vivid image or idiom—a rattling wind-sifter on a dusty planet, the jangle of worn leather chaps against a control panel—and let that define the flavor. • Dialogue will feel lived-in, with half-finished sentences, slang that drifts in and out of focus, and the occasional stutter or mispronunciation. 3. Embracing Imperfection & Surprise • Humans will let mistakes, dead ends, or half-realized ideas stay in the draft. They’ll circle back, re-use or even celebrate them, creating happy accidents—a stray line of dialogue that leads to a new subplot, for instance. • They’re comfortable with uneven pacing, moments of quiet that don’t demand suspense, or an ending that doesn’t tie up every loose thread. 4. Layering Subtext & Ambiguity • A real writer will play with what’s unsaid: the Captain’s guilt over a lost crew member isn’t spelled out in an info-dump but revealed through a lingering shot of an empty bunk or a character’s hesitation at touch. • They’ll let the creature’s true nature remain partly inscrutable, so readers wrestle with their own judgments. # Common LLM Tropes & Why They Might Not Serve This Piece 1. “Playing It Safe” • LLMs often default to non-offensive, broadly acceptable choices—generic settings, mild conflicts, predictable twists. • For a visceral Space Western with real dread, we need sharper stakes and riskier moral ambiguity. 2. “Tying Up With a Bow” • LLMs frequently resolve every subplot and moral dilemma neatly. • Here, the story’s power lies in lingering questions—did the symbiote truly understand compassion? Who else will come looking for it? 3. “Impressive Vocabulary Over Readability” • There’s a temptation to sprinkle in sci-fi jargon (“quantum manifold,” “bio-resistive membrane”) in lieu of immersive detail. • Readers care more about the grit under a boot tread or the metallic tang of blood on a fingertip. 4. “Formulaic Structure & Beats” • An eight-chapter breakdown with predictable cliffhangers is serviceable but can ring hollow if every beat feels mechanically placed. • Real pacing breathes—some chapters might be sparse and meditative, others frantic and disorienting. # Critique of the Current Intention & Plan 1. Overly Neat Tone Specification • “Gritty” + “slow horror” + “each chapter must end on a cliff” reads like a style guide, not a living, breathing atmosphere. • Risk: The story will feel choreographed rather than organically tense. 2. Archetypal Characters • Captain-as-veteran, First Mate-ex-marshal, Engineer-idealist… all useful, but they lack quirks. • Risk: They’d sound interchangeable with any other LLM-generated crew. 3. Predictable Plot Beats • Crate rattles → crate opens → crew splits along kill vs. save lines → corporate twist → final showdown → ambiguous hook. • Risk: Readers will guess every beat in advance. The corporate bio-weapon reveal at Chapter 5 is a cliché mid-book twist. 4. Cliffhangers on Cue • Every chapter ends with a “dilemma or scare,” which may feel forced. • Risk: The tension becomes a treadmill; readers grow desensitized. 5. Creature as “Juvenile Symbiote” • A solid choice, but we haven’t defined what makes *this* creature distinct: its physiology, its psychology, its “voice.” • Risk: It remains another faceless alien trope. # Brainstorming Ways to Make It More Human 1. Flesh Out Personal Stakes • Give the Captain a tangible emotional wound: maybe the creature’s behavior echoes a lost child’s cries, dredging up paternal grief. • Let the Engineer’s fascination be rooted in a real memory—like an old science fair gone wrong. 2. Inject Imperfect, Specific Detail • Instead of “neon-lit cantinas,” describe how the neon flickers when someone farts gas through a broken airfilter. • The crate hums at 237 hertz—an exact frequency that reminds the Medic of her anxious mother’s sewing machine. 3. Subvert the Mid-Story Twist • Rather than “corporate says kill it,” let the corporation’s message be garbled, conflicting, or optional—forcing the crew to piece it together. • Or have two corporate directives in opposition, raising the question: which shadow power do you obey? 4. Vary the Pacing • One chapter could be a quiet diary entry from the Creature’s point of view—its first impressions of metal walls, neon signs, the crew’s scent. • Another could be a high-octane dogfight with a privateer skiff overhead, distracting them from the cargo hold entirely. 5. Characters’ Quirks & Mistakes • The First Mate might have a tic—spray tobacco spittle whenever he lies or feels ashamed. • The Medic’s calming mantra could be an out-of-sync children’s lullaby that rings false under stress. 6. Dialogue That Breathes • Snatches of half-cut lines: “Y’know, when this is over—” “Don’t jinx it, Janeway!” • Unexpected colloquialisms: “That crate gives me the old goose takes.” 7. Deeper Creature Design • Give it a sensory quirk—a glimmering bio-luminescent pattern that mirrors crew emotions. • Let it try to communicate via stolen phrases: humming the Engineer’s favorite lullaby in static bursts. 8. Ambiguous, Emotional Ending • Perhaps the creature escapes but leaves behind a piece of itself—like a bio-filament—and the Captain plants it at a frontier station, hoping it grows into something redeeming. • Or the ship’s log ends with a half-erased entry: “If you’re reading this… I’m sorry.” By consciously breaking from “safe” LLM defaults—injecting personal stakes, sensory specificity, uneven pacing, and genuine moral messiness—we’ll craft a short story that feels lived in, unpredictable, and emotionally resonant.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention We’re telling a taut, character-driven Space Western that lives and breathes through sensory detail, imperfect dialogue, and real emotional stakes—no safety nets, no tidy bows. Central to the story is a lone, juvenile symbiote in a rattling crate and the ragged crew who wrestle with fear, loss, and profit. Voice & Style • Gritty, lived-in frontier: neon sputters, recycled air smells of oil and dust. • Show, don’t tell: use small details (a tremor in the Captain’s voice, tobacco spit when the First Mate lies) to reveal character. • Dialogue that stumbles: half-finished thoughts, slang, false starts. • Varied pacing: one chapter’s a quiet, almost meditative POV; the next is a high-stakes dogfight or firefight. • Ambiguity & loose threads: moral questions remain unsettled; last image haunts beyond the final page. Characters & Creature • Captain Rosetta “Ross” Hayes: haunted by the disappearance of her own child, driven by guilt and a fierce code. • First Mate Jonas “Hawk” Crow: ex-marshal, spittle betrays him when he feels shame or fear. • Engineer T’Mari “Tia” Chen: brilliant, curious, recalled to a childhood science fair accident. • Medic Dr. Linh Vu: empathetic, murmurs a half-remembered lullaby under stress. • Cargo Spec Cade Klem: mercenary with shifting loyalties and a secret corporate override code. • The Symbiote: juvenile, translucent skin lit by bio-luminescent fractals that mirror crew emotions; repeats stolen voices in soft telepathic pulses. Plot & Beats • Ground the horror in human emotion—paternal grief, scientific wonder, corporate betrayal. • Foreshadow through glitchy instruments, lost tools, and whispers in the vents. • Subvert a single mid-story twist by making corporate orders contradictory, forcing the crew to choose their own ethics. • Alternate chapters between quiet dread (including a creature-centered POV) and frantic action (dogfights, firefights). • Let the climax be both physical and moral: no easy “good vs. evil,” only survival, sacrifice, and regret. • End on an open question: the crate still hums, and so do the Captain’s doubts. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – “Karwin’s Rest” (Setup, ~1,000 words) • Scene: under flickering neon at a frontier port, Hayes’ crew negotiates for the sealed crate. • Sensory hooks: dust-choked air, acid tang of spilled coolant, rattling footsteps in a back-alley cantina. • Quick intros: Hawk’s spittle as he lies about ship’s condition; Tia adjusting her scanner with a nervous tic. • Final beat: a low hum at precisely 237 Hz—crate vibration so strong it rattles the ship’s bulkhead. Chapter 2 – “Glitches” (Escalation) • En route: small anomalies multiply—nav-computer flickers, a toolbox strap is sliced open by unseen claws. • Lullaby motif: Dr. Vu sleep-talks a warped children’s song; the melody echoes in the vents. • Crew dynamics: Hawk demands brute force solutions; Tia insists on data. • Final beat: Tia spots a pale limb pressed against a crate porthole—just for a heartbeat. Chapter 3 – “Loose Ends” (Turning Point) • Turbulence in a star-crane corridor: crate latch fails, doors swing open. • Creature escape: acid-sharp air, a flash of bio-light, a damaged maintenance drone smeared with black ichor. • Injury: A deckhand nicked by claws bleeds thick green plasma. • Final beat: Hayes pauses at the junction, hears her own voice calling down the hall—her voice, not on comms. Chapter 4 – “I See You” (Creature & First Contact) • Two POV threads, alternating: – Creature: disoriented wonder at metal ribs, tastes fear as a new scent. Bio-fractals flicker in rainbow pulses. – Hayes: runs a handheld EMF scanner, recognizes a pattern in the light. • Creature mimics a dead crewman’s voice via ship speakers, begging “Don’t hurt me.” • Tension: Tia slips behind a grated door, offers water; Creature tilts its head, curious. • Final beat: Creature flares a fractal pattern that spells out a single word on the bulkhead: “Home?” Chapter 5 – “Shadows of Command” (External Crisis & Corporate Twist) • A corporate task skiff drops out of hyperspace—plasma bolts pepper the hull. Crew scrambles to fighters. • Mid-fight: garbled override from Cade Klem’s implant: “Eliminate specimen. All crew expendable.” • Hayes intercepts a second directive, conflicting: “Preserve at all costs.” • Final beat: comms blackout seals them in; outside fighters circle like sharks. Chapter 6 – “Blood and Bone” (Lines Drawn) • Debate spirals: Hawk and Cade arm plasma rifles; Tia rigs a stasis harness; Dr. Vu begs for mercy. • Hayes’ guilt surfaces: she sees the creature’s eyes, remembers a crying child in a Ranger station. • An argument explodes into violence—Tia shoves Cade into a corridor, Hawk holds a gun on Dr. Vu. • Final beat: Hayes slams her palm to a console, vortex locks down—doors hiss shut. Chapter 7 – “Barnburner” (Climax) • All-out firefight in the cargo bay: sparking conduits, strobe-flash bio-light, shouts drowned by alarms. • Creature tries to interface with the jump drive—system overload threatens to incinerate the hold. • Hayes confronts Cade over the override. Cade flees; Hawk hesitates. Tia races to reroute power. • Sacrifice: someone dives to hold a vent open, letting the creature slip away. • Final beat: Hayes yanks the manual afterburner—jump ignition, everything goes white. Chapter 8 – “Afterglow” (Aftermath & Ambiguous Echo) • Dawn on the far side of a gas giant—ship limps into sparse gravity, survivors count the cost. • Scorched floor, two bodies wrapped in tarps, Hawk nursing a plasma graze. Tia combs wreckage for data. • Dr. Vu finds a single bio-filament glowing in the sealed bay—alive. • Final image & line: Hayes presses her palm to the crate’s door one last time. Faint hum answers. “Who’s home now?”
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Rosetta “Ross” Hayes Background & Personality • Born on Drya Prime, a dusty frontier world. Father was a small-time smuggler who vanished on a run. Ross learned to shoot from age ten, chasing bandits to pay off debts. • Lost her only child, Mara, in a shuttle accident two years ago. Since then, she’s been driven by guilt and a fierce need to protect anyone regarded as “family.” • Stoic and pragmatic under fire, but in quiet moments her shoulders slump and her eyes fix on empty space. Idiosyncrasies & Flaws • Carries a tarnished silver locket with a lock of her daughter’s hair—she fingers it when anxious. • Hums an old nursery rhyme when sleep-talking (“Star light, star bright…”)—crew wakes to catch her whispering in the dark. • Struggles to trust others fully; shoulders every burden alone until she nearly breaks. Physicality • Mid-40s, lean and weather-worn. A diagonal scar runs from her temple to cheekbone, souvenir of a skirmish on a mining moon. • Wears a faded leather duster patched with cloth from Mara’s favorite dress. Keeps her pistol low-slung at her hip. • Moves with deliberate economy—every step measured, eyes constantly scanning. Motives & Relationships • Core motive: redemption for her child’s death by saving lives or at least not letting another die needlessly. • Allegiance: loyally protective of her crew; mistrustful of corporate orders. • Relationships: – Mentor-figure to Dr. Vu, sensing the same compassion she lost. – Tense but respectful bond with Hawk—mutual trust tested by his black-and-white law mindset. Sample Voice • Internal Monologue: “Every decision’s on me. If I fail again, I’ll drown in the wreckage of what could’ve been.” • Dialogue: “No one gets left behind—except when the odds say they’re already gone.” # Jonas “Hawk” Crow Background & Personality • Former marshal on New Ceres, booted out after he defied orders to stand down during a civilian riot. Believes in upholding order by any means. • Haunted by the massacre he prevented—300 lives lost when he ran out of options. Operates under a rigid moral code that seldom bends. Idiosyncrasies & Flaws • Habitually chews strong black tobacco; spittle flecks whenever he lies or feels guilt. • Polishes his old–West revolver every night, reciting case numbers like a mantra. • Flaw: his sense of duty blinds him to nuance; he sees the world in absolutes—threat vs. law. Physicality • Broad-shouldered, six-feet-two, with cropped black hair streaked by early gray. • Walks with a confident swagger, chest thrust forward; when angry, fists clench at his side. • Cold gray eyes that study threats—and people—like a judge weighs evidence. Motives & Relationships • Core motive: enforce rules to keep chaos at bay. He’d rather burn out one ship than let anarchy spread. • Allegiance: first to the rule of law, second to Captain Hayes (though he resents when her decisions drift from his black-and-white view). • Relationships: – Clashes with Tia’s free-spirit tinkering, respects her skill but distrusts her optimism. – Protective of Dr. Vu, whom he sees as innocent, yet resents her soft heart. Sample Voice • Internal Monologue: “Rules are the only thing been with me longer than this uniform. No one breaks them on my watch.” • Dialogue: “We don’t debate whether the thing’s scared—we neutralize the threat, period.” # T’Mari “Tia” Chen Background & Personality • Child prodigy from Orin Colony—built her first hover-engine at twelve. Won a science fair that ended in a lab fire; a friend was badly burned. She’s never quite shaken that guilt. • Bright-eyed, quick to laugh, sees the universe as a puzzle worth solving—questions everything, from sentient aliens to the Captain’s nightmare fuel. Idiosyncrasies & Flaws • Talks to machines as if they’re people, calling them “Darling” or “Sweetheart.” • Collects broken scrap—says she’s “rescuing potential.” Her quarters overflow with half-finished gadgets. • Flaw: overconfidence leads her to underestimate danger; hyperfocus on tech sometimes blinds her to human cost. Physicality • Petite and wiry, rolls agile shoulders under a jumpsuit smeared with grease. Forearms bear faint mechanical-burn scars. • Dark hair in a perpetually messy bun, streaked with silver from an electrical mishap. • Moves in quick, energetic bursts, fingers always tapping or twisting something. Motives & Relationships • Core motive: prove that science—and empathy—can solve unknowns. She sees the symbiote as a marvel, not a monster. • Allegiance: to the search for knowledge, then to the Captain who let her stay aboard. • Relationships: – Best friends with Dr. Vu—Tia cracks jokes to ease Linh’s nightmares. – Teases Hawk mercilessly, but admires his resolve deep down. Sample Voice • Internal Monologue: “If only I can recalibrate those neural dampers, maybe it’ll tell me what it’s feeling. Or at least flash a tantrum pattern I can decode.” • Dialogue: “C’mon, Hawk—your old revolver’s cooler-looking than my plasma torch, but it won’t help us learn its birth frequency.” # Dr. Linh Vu Background & Personality • Raised in the flooded domes of Anzio Station, trained as a clinical medic. Left the corporate health corps when they sold experimental drugs to frontier worlds. • Soft-spoken and observant, she carries a quiet authority in crisis—knows exactly where to press flesh, set bone, or soothe panic. Idiosyncrasies & Flaws • Hums fragments of her mother’s lullabies under stress; forgotten lyrics echo as half-sentences. • Tends a tiny hydroponic sprig of maize in a glass vial—watches it grow like a child. • Flaw: so desperate to save everything that she hesitates to pull the trigger on tough calls, risking the many for the one. Physicality • Average height, warm brown eyes that soften under lamplight. Smooth skin with a surgical-glove tan line on her wrist. • Moves with gentle confidence—each touch purposeful. Carries a worn leather satchel of medical tools cross-body. Motives & Relationships • Core motive: to preserve life, alien or human. Sees the symbiote as another patient in need. • Allegiance: to sentient beings first; crew second if lives hang in the balance. • Relationships: – Surrogate sister to Tia—together they whisper theories over midnight coffee. – Peacekeeper between Hayes and Hawk, often pulled into their moral crossfire. Sample Voice • Internal Monologue: “Its bioluminescent pulses slow when I lower the lights. Fear is universal—maybe trust is, too.” • Dialogue: “We can’t let panic write this creature’s obituary. A measured approach might save us all.” # Cade Klem Background & Personality • Grew up in Corvex City’s corporate sprawl, did black-ops for a megacorp before turning freelance. Knows how to read a ledger—and a person—for profit. • Slick, always polite, with a disarming half-smile that rarely reaches his eyes. Idiosyncrasies & Flaws • Constantly checks an implanted corporate comm badge—taps it when uneasy. • Keeps a stack of pristine credit chits in his pocket, even though he claims to be “off the books.” • Flaw: his loyalty shifts with the highest bidder; under pressure, cracks in his charm reveal a jittery pragmatist. Physicality • Lean and angular, three-day stubble framing thin lips. A jagged scar bisects his lower lip—he brushes it absently when lying. • Dresses in tailored smarts that look expensive even after a firefight. Wire-rim glasses perched on his nose, rarely clean. Motives & Relationships • Core motive: secure the highest payout and keep one step ahead of corporate debt. • Allegiance: corporate interests above all—until they prove a liability. • Relationships: – Hayes hired him grudgingly; he bristles at her moralizing. – Hawk sees him as a slippery weasel. – Tries to charm Tia into sharing tech secrets; she keeps him at arm’s length. Sample Voice • Internal Monologue: “They’re staring at me like I’m the villain in their bedtime story. Funny—I always thought I was the hero of mine.” • Dialogue: “Listen, Captain, this isn’t personal—just business. You want your ship intact, you play along.”

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 1 – Karwin’s Rest The neon overhead sputters and coughs, splattering acid-green light across Lanquell Street. Dust drifts in lazy spirals beneath the glow, coating boots and scanners alike. Ross Hayes stands in the open doorway of the cantina, leather duster trailing rusty footprints across the metal threshold. She fingers the tarnished silver locket at her collarbone—her daughter’s curl bound inside—and inhales the acrid scent of spent coolant and machine oil. Out here, on Drya Prime’s fringe, nothing comes cheap, and nothing stays sound for long. Behind her, Jonas “Hawk” Crow shoves a fist into a holster, chewing strong black tobacco with a practiced grunt. A fleck of spittle lands against the reinforced doorframe. He studies the crowd of smugglers, star-traders, and derelict hull-pickers milling under flickering signage. “They late,” he mutters, jaw set. T’Mari “Tia” Chen adjusts her scanner—a battered, reconfigured relic of the Orin Colony Science Fair—murmuring to it: “C’mon, sweetheart, tell me you picked up something besides Standard Crate Vibration.” Her dark hair is tied in a messy bun, loose strands catching sparks from a brazing torch at work nearby. She taps the scanner’s edge, sending a flicker of data across her goggles. Dr. Linh Vu stands a few paces away, cradling a tiny hydroponic vial in one hand. A sprig of maize leans inside the glass, roots glistening in nutrient solution. Linh hums a half-forgotten lullaby—her mother’s voice, warped by hunger and rain-soaked nights. The melody drifts through the din, soft enough to worry Ross. “Captain.” Cade Klem approaches in tailored slacks and a duster that matches no local style. He brushes a line of dust from wire-rim glasses. His lean face lifts in a polite half-smile. His implanted comm badge pulses faintly beneath his collar. Cade taps the badge with a fingertip. “Our contact’s loaded the crate. We’re clear to move on this side.” He glances at Ross’s locket. “Interesting piece.” Ross nods once, glancing back at the makeshift docking bay where a hulking flatcar waits under warbling floodlights. “Show me.” They cross the street beneath a neon hawk sign—its image uncannily like Hawk’s silhouette, talons outstretched. The bay’s air smells of burning hydrazine and old sweat. The flatcar’s deck is crowded with mismatched cargo: rerouted nuclear cores, sacks of spice roots, and one sealed metal crate painted a dull gray. A man in a patched jumpsuit stands guard. At Ross’s approach, he lifts a battered helmet, revealing a scar-split grin. “Captain Hayes,” he says. His voice rattles in a reclaimed comm speaker strapped to his belt. “I got your crate right here. Condition’s prime.” He taps the crate’s side. “Low hum, keeps everything—stable.” Ross scans the lid’s rivets and the welded seams. “Spec says non-porous, pressure-locked. No vents?” She steps closer, boots clanking on the gridded deck. “None. Up to spec.” The handler waves a gauntleted hand at Cade. “Your man did the paperwork.” Cade steps forward, flipping data-credits onto the handler’s palm. The credits glow holographically before dissolving into the man’s battered gauntlet. “Pleasure doing business. Let’s keep it that way.” He ducks under a cable hanging like a noose and signals Tia. Tia kneels beside the crate, scanner clasped to her ear. “Strange power signature,” she says in a half-whisper. “Uniform, but something in the matrix is oscillating unpredictably. See this?” She points to a circular ridged hatch at the crate’s center. The handler smirks. “That’s your inspection port. Safe enough to peek, if you fancy. We painters left a reinforced viewport down there.” He nods to a smaller panel sealed by four clamps. Ross lifts one clamp with a flick of her right hand. A soft hiss issues forth—hardly audible over the engines beyond—and a tiny port cover slides back. Ross crouches and peers in. Her breath fogs the glass for an instant, then she blinks. Inside, darkness. Empty. She straightens. “No readings but the hum. Cade?” He approaches, glancing at Hawk. “Clear enough. Let’s get it aboard.” Hawk slaps the crate’s side. “Hook it up, crew.” Two deckhands attach magnetic harnesses, yanking the crate toward the ship’s loading ramp. Ross notes the handle’s worn edges and a tiny scratch that arrests her eye. It looks unnatural—like a claw might have scraped it. Linh steps to Ross’s side. Without breaking her lullaby song, she closes her eyes. “I feel… pressure. Something alive inside.” She unclasps the vial’s cap, holds the sprig of maize outward. “I want to check for… growth indicators. With your leave.” Ross gives a curt nod. “When we’re clear of port. For now, move.” She watches the crate ascend, machinery whining. The crowd on Lanquell Street flows back into the night: traders, scavvers, lost souls looking for passage off-world. Inside the ship’s belly, the hatch engulfs them. The hold’s lights are low and red-tinged. Ross steps aboard first, helmet under arm. She hears Hawk’s heavy boots behind her, the hiss of dampers from Tia’s scanner, and Linh’s soft hum. “Secure the harness.” Ross’s voice echoes off corrugated steel walls. The crate settles on reinforced beams, bolted to the deck beneath. Cade flicks a panel on the console, sealing environmental membranes. He glances at Ross. “All set, Captain.” She flips a switch to dim the overhead red lights. As the hatch seals, Ross leans back against a pillar. The crate vibrates beneath her glove. She tilts her head, listening. Then: a low, sonorous hum ripples through the hold. It’s steady at first, then rises and falls, almost like a sigh. Tia’s scanner chirps wildly—data streaming too fast to track. Linh drops her vial in surprise; the maize sprig rattles against the glass. Hawk spins, hand on his revolver, spittle flecking the floor. Ross closes her eyes, hum guiding her memories. She’d once comforted Mara to the same lullaby tune, humming through tears. Now the hum is different—alien, resonant. It vibrates at precisely 237 hertz, shuddering through the crate’s walls. The floor plates tremble. The bulkhead shudders. The humming swells, as if the crate itself is breathing. And then the lights flicker, and the ship rocks on its moorings, answering a call Ross doesn’t yet understand.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively establishes the space western setting through sensory details and character introductions. The author creates a gritty, lived-in frontier world with "neon overhead sputters and coughs," "dust drifts in lazy spirals," and the "acrid scent of spent coolant and machine oil." These details immediately ground us in a tangible environment that feels authentic to the genre. The character introductions are handled with subtlety, revealing personalities through actions rather than exposition. Ross Hayes is established as the stoic captain with a tragic past, fingering her locket containing her daughter's curl. Hawk's spitting tobacco and rigid demeanor reveal his no-nonsense approach. Tia's relationship with technology and Linh's quiet empathy are shown through their behaviors. Cade's corporate connections and questionable loyalty are hinted at through his attire and the pulsing comm badge. The dialogue is serviceable but occasionally stiff. Some exchanges feel functional rather than natural, particularly when characters are explaining plot points. The dialect and speech patterns don't always differentiate characters as strongly as they could. The plot setup is straightforward but effective—a mysterious crate with something alive inside it. The chapter builds tension gradually, culminating in the reveal that whatever is in the crate produces a resonant hum that affects both the ship and the crew. The connection to Ross's memories of her daughter adds emotional weight. The writing occasionally veers into purple prose with phrases like "splattering acid-green light" and "dust drifts in lazy spirals," but these moments are generally in service of world-building rather than mere decoration. The author mostly avoids telling-not-showing, though there are a few instances where character traits are stated rather than demonstrated. The chapter follows the plan quite faithfully, including the sensory hooks, character introductions, and the final beat with the humming crate. It establishes the space western setting and introduces the central mystery effectively. The characters are consistent with their profiles, exhibiting the traits and behaviors outlined. However, the chapter could benefit from more distinctive dialogue and deeper character interactions. While we get glimpses of the relationships between crew members, these could be more fully developed. The pacing is somewhat slow, with much of the chapter devoted to setting and character introduction rather than advancing the plot. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 2 – Glitches The Maelstrom’s engines thrum beneath Ross Hayes’s boots as the cargo hold hisses shut around the crate. She strides to the starboard catwalk and taps a console. The red lights dim, revealing the gray metal of the sealed crate. A low hum rolls through the beams like distant thunder. In the cockpit, T’Mari “Tia” Chen leans over a holographic chart, fingers dancing across a mesh of star lanes. Her scanner’s readouts flicker with erratic spikes. “Negative yaw alignment,” she says, voice tight. “Nav rig’s glitching around the crate’s EM signature. I’m recalibrating—” A stutter in her words, and the nav map shivers. A stripe of green jumps off-course by half a degree. “Hell,” Ross growls from the pilot’s seat. She grips her yoke, nudges the stick. The stars slide back into alignment. Jonas “Hawk” Crow stands behind her, arms crossed, revolver butt brushing his hip. “That crate’s a magnet for trouble,” he mutters, almost to himself. He chews tobacco, spittle pooling at the corner of his jaw. “We should’ve jettisoned it before we left Drya orbit.” Ross doesn’t answer. She glances at Cade Klem, sitting primly in the navigator’s chair, tapping a battered datapad. His wire-rim glasses catch reflection from the control panel. He offers a polite nod but says nothing. Below decks, in the starboard workshop, Tia’s scanner clicks into a higher pitch. She ducks under a hanging tool rack. The open toolbox beside her holds empty slots: multitool, plasma cutter, a coil of durasteel wire. The strap binding the box has been sliced clean through—edges curled, as if carved by claws. “Crap.” Tia traces the jagged tear with a fingertip, eyes wide. She slides her sleeve down to catch a smear of oily black fluid. Not rust, not grease—something organic. She swallows. “Something’s inside, and it’s roaming.” Back in the cockpit, Dr. Linh Vu reclines in a med-bunk off to the side, outfitted with restraining straps and diagnostic scanners. She’s off-duty but tends to her hydroponic vial—watery roots twining around her slender fingers. Her eyes flutter shut. Through the bulkhead, faint and wavering, a lullaby drifts: “Star light… star bright…” The melody warps like an old phonograph scratched by dust. The lines loop at odd intervals—“First star I… First star I…”—over and over. Tia swivels in her chair. “Is that Linh?” Hawk’s scowl deepens. “She’s asleep. That was her promise song—’First Star I See’—you military types must’ve heard it.” Cade shrugs. “Comfort music. Not my problem.” Ross’s jaw clenches. “Keep the volume low. I don’t want the crew rattled before we even hit the outer rim.” The lullaby stutters and the lights flicker in staccato pulses. Ross glances at the overhead panel: “Auxiliary power drop to twenty-three percent.” She slaps the input pad. “Reboot auxiliary channel three.” “You got it.” Cade’s fingers dance over the display. The lights stabilize, but only slightly. A persistent hum in the hull vibrates the soles of their boots. For an hour, they drift in uneasy silence. The inside of the hold is colder than the cockpit—metal walls warped from age, condensation beading on pipes. Ross descends the catwalk, scanner in hand. She stops at the crate’s side, places her palm flat against the cool surface, and listens. The hum is rhythmic now—three pulses per second. “Commander Hayes,” Tia’s voice crackles over comm. “I’m picking up something else. Thermal reads—almost nothing. But there’s a warm spot right behind the panel. And a distortion in the magnetic field.” Ross kneels, taps a panel. “Open her up,” she orders. Hawk raises his revolver. “Wait. That’s cross-contamination waiting to happen. We don’t know what it is.” Tia exchanges a look with Ross. “Or it’s a life-form, frozen or sleeping. We need data before we vaporize it.” Ross’s eyes flick between them. “I’m not gunning it down.” She glances at Cade. “Power to clamps?” Cade sighs. “On it.” Sparks sizzle as the clamps unlatch. The panel slides aside with a pneumatic hiss. Ross shines her helmet lamp into the circular aperture. Darkness. No creature, no fluid, no wires—just blackness. She straightens. “Cable’s empty.” Tia’s scanner whines. “It’s behind the panel. I’ll remove the second layer.” She grips a plasma torch. “Stand back.” Hawk’s finger twitches over his trigger. “I told you—” Before he can finish, Tia’s torch sears metal. Ratchets clatter. A shape unspools behind the wall: pale, bulbous, flesh like translucent silk. Ross steps back. “Pull it back! Pull it back now!” Tia retreats. The creature’s form vanishes as quickly as it appeared. Sparks flare. They slam the panel shut. Lock bolts hiss. The crate hums louder. Hawk breathes hard, tobacco sweat darkening his collar. “That’s no machine.” Cade peers at the sealed wall. “Looks organic.” Ross steadies her voice. “We log it, we monitor it.” She taps her comm. “Bridge—course plot for Ganymar Station, next jump. No deviations.” The lullaby returns, louder, echoing through the hull. Linh’s voice, full and clear: “First star I see tonight… I wish I may…” Ross grips a bulkhead rail. “What the hell.” Tia adjusts her goggles. “I’m getting phasic readings—something’s walking hullside.” Hawk levels his revolver at the crate. “Ready to engage.” Cade’s eyes flicker between consoles. “Multiple override pings incoming. Must be corporate HQ.” The crate’s hum spikes, jarring the steel beams. The hold’s lights dim to darkness for a heartbeat. Ross’s lamp flickers, then dies. The humming penetrates bone. Tia yanks a backup lamp from her belt and flicks it on. The beam falls on the porthole in the crate’s center. For a single breath, she sees it: a slender, pale limb pressed against the glass, joints bending in an impossible angle. Bioluminescent fractals flare across its skin, pulsing in time with the hum. Then it’s gone. The crate’s surface is still and silent—almost polite. No furrows, no indentations, nothing to betray the moment before. Ross exhales, voice hollow. “Lock it down. All channels secure.” Hawk holsters his weapon, jaw set. “We’re knee-deep in something that’ll kill us.” Tia’s hand trembles on the scanner. “Or something we can learn from. But we’re running out of time.” Cade swipes at his badge. “They’ll want answers.” Above them, in the darkness of space, the Maelstrom slides toward its next destination. Inside, fear and wonder jostle for control—while something unseen studies them all.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively builds tension through a series of escalating anomalies aboard the ship, as outlined in the writing plan. The model successfully introduces the mysterious creature in the crate through subtle hints and brief glimpses rather than direct exposition, creating an atmosphere of mounting dread. The characters are generally consistent with their profiles. Ross Hayes maintains her stoic leadership while harboring underlying guilt and protectiveness. Hawk demonstrates his black-and-white worldview and readiness to neutralize threats. Tia shows her scientific curiosity and eagerness to understand rather than destroy. Dr. Linh Vu's lullaby serves as both character development and plot device. Cade remains somewhat detached and pragmatic. The sensory details are well-executed, particularly the persistent hum that "penetrates bone" and the flickering lights that create an unsettling atmosphere. The chapter effectively uses environmental cues to signal the creature's presence: the sliced toolbox strap, the oily black fluid, the thermal readings, and finally the brief glimpse of a pale limb against the porthole. However, there are some weaknesses. The dialogue occasionally feels stilted, with characters making declarative statements that serve plot functions rather than revealing personality ("That's no machine." "Looks organic."). Some character reactions feel underdeveloped - we're told Tia's hand trembles but don't get deeper insight into her emotional state beyond surface observations. The chapter follows most elements of the plan, including the nav-computer glitches, toolbox anomalies, Dr. Vu's lullaby, and the glimpse of the creature at the porthole. However, it doesn't fully develop the crew dynamics as outlined in the plan - Hawk demands brute force solutions and Tia insists on data, but their conflict feels somewhat perfunctory rather than deeply rooted in their characters. The writing occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when describing emotional states ("Ross's jaw clenches" rather than revealing her thoughts). Some descriptions are somewhat generic ("fear and wonder jostle for control") rather than specific to these characters in this situation. Overall, the chapter successfully builds tension and mystery while establishing the core conflict between those who want to destroy the unknown creature and those who want to understand it. It's faithful to the space western prompt and effectively sets up future developments. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 7 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 16 Followed Chapter Plan: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 3 – Loose Ends The Maelstrom shudders as hyperspace slipstream slams the hull. Ross Hayes’s knuckles whiten on the throttle yoke. The crate in the hold rattles like a steel coffin caught in a stampede. Sparks flare on the bulkhead above her head, and the red warning lights strobe in panic rhythm. “Status?” she barks. T’Mari “Tia” Chen leans over the nav console, feet braced. Her scanner chirps wild data. “EM field’s spiking—crate’s oscillating at subharmonic resonance. We’re hitting turbulence pockets in the slipstream.” Jonas “Hawk” Crow lifts one boot from the deckplate and lets it drop with a thud. “Tell it to shut up,” he growls. Spittle beads at his lip. Ross kicks the yoke forward. “Reduce slipstream throttle by three percent—ease her through.” She flicks a switch, dampers hiss. The ship shivers; the crate’s hum warps into a keening wail. Below decks, in the maintenance bay, a service drone scuttles along rails, welding circuits on a damaged conduit. Its optical sensors flicker, then shut off. The crate’s unholy resonance floods the bay. Joints seize, sparks fly. The drone’s hull cracks open—black fluid seeps out. It spasms twice, then falls silent. Tia’s voice crackles over comm. “Motive power failing in cargo hold—drone’s down.” “On it,” Ross says, punching the intercom. “Hawk, Linh—report to lower decks. Tia, stay cockpit-side; monitor systems.” * In the hold’s gloom, emergency red lights bathe the crate in blood-tint. Ross strides down the metal catwalk to the grated floor. Beneath, oil-dark fluid pools: the maintenance drone’s innards mixed with something unnamable—tar-like ichor that hisses where it touches metal. Dr. Linh Vu kneels beside a deckhand slumped against a support column. The man’s coveralls are torn; green plasma crusts his sleeve where claws raked him. Linh works quickly, pressing a hydro-gel pad to the wound. She hums the broken lullaby: “Star bright… star bright…” The deckhand winces, eyes rolling. “Bleeding stabilized,” she reports. “But the tissue around the wound—cell structure’s altered. No biotech in my database matches this.” Ross crouches beside Linh, shining her helmet lamp on the wound. The plasma’s veins pulse, bioluminescent fractals crawling beneath skin like living tattoos. “We need to contain exposure.” She glances at Hawk, who’s wiping tobacco-stained sweat from his brow. “Keep others back. Seal the bay.” Hawk stamps the red button. An alarm bleats. The hold’s bulkhead doors begin to close—metal plates sliding downward. Sparks rain as the carriage snaps into lockdown. * Back in the cockpit, Cade Klem taps his badge. “Override codes inbound—corporate HQ is firing commands to open that bay. They’re not waiting for us to decide.” Tia’s voice quavers. “If we open that bay, whatever’s in the crate will escape the locks entirely. And we’re sitting ducks in space.” Cade runs his thumb over the badge’s pulsing light. “Kid gloves, people. HQ wants data. I can push a counter-code, but they’ll see it as a hostile act.” Ross leans back in her seat, eyes to the viewport. Stars twist into lines. Her heart thuds against her ribs. “Do it.” She steels herself. “Counter-code—jam their signal. We’ll decide.” * The bay doors clang shut. The last sliver of red light vanishes as the crate’s hold seals. But behind that closure, the hendrick-sized box shakes violently. A bolt shatters. The crate’s latch gives way. Ross feels the shockwave shake through her bones. “By the Maker,” she whispers. The hull groans. Emergency corridors light up in stuttering blue. Ross drops the yoke. “Report!” Tia’s voice cracks. “Systems reorienting for green jump—wait, no—power diverting to all corridors. They’re turning the ship into a maze of live conduits.” Cade curses. “It’s adapting to contain the crate’s resonance! We’re getting locked in.” Ross leaps from her seat. “We move downstairs. Now.” * They race the twisting stairwell. Metal grates underfoot, handrails slick with condensation. Ross’s lamp cuts through the gloom as Hawk and Tia flank her. Shrieking alarms bounce off the bulkheads. At the hold entrance, the panel’s ripped open. The crate lies on its side—hinges torn free, shards of durasteel scattered like splinters. The crate’s hum is a ragged howl, echoing down every deck. “Jesus,” Tia breathes. “It’s gone.” Hawk flips his revolver open. “Search in pairs. I’ll take Sector C with Linh.” “Right,” Ross says. “Tia, stay with me. Cade, coordinate the grids—relaunch turbulence if it helps drive it back.” Cade nods, fingers flying across a wrist console. “Sector maps re-routing. Corridor Delta sealed off. Good luck.” They split. Ross and Tia head starboard, stepping over the drone’s blood. Hall lights flicker, then fade. Emergency floor lamps blaze, casting long shadows. Tia’s scanner pings. “I’m getting phasic blips—something’s crawling along the external bulkhead. I can’t get a visual.” Ross grips the rail. “Stay close. If it breaches the hull…” She doesn’t finish the sentence. She doesn’t need to. They round a corner into Corridor C14. The lights flicker out completely. All they have is Tia’s scanner and Ross’s lamp. The corridor expands into a widening vent—metal ribs arch overhead like a cathedral. “Did you seal the vents?” Ross asks. Tia shakes her head. “Signal’s overridden the airlocks. The power flux did it.” A soft scuttle echoes ahead. Ross’s breath catches. She levels her lamp into the darkness. For a heartbeat, nothing moves. Then: a pale shape darts across the far wall—limbs bending in angles no human joint should allow. A streak of bioluminescent fractals flares white before vanishing around a corner. Ross’s throat goes dry. “After it!” They sprint, lights dancing on walls slick with oily residue. Tia’s scanner trails glowing blips around the bend—proximal sensors discreetly triggered then cut. Ross’s heart hammers; she knows they’re trailing a predator. At the junction, Ross’s lamp sweeps left, then right. The corridor forks. From the left, a whisper: her own voice. Soft, intimate, calling her name—“Captain Hayes…” No comm feed, no speaker. Just her voice, echoing. Tia stumbles, catching her elbow. “Did you hear—?” Ross holds up her hand. “Shh.” She steps forward, hairline scar paling under the helmet light. “Somebody’s messing with us.” Another whisper—this time urgent: “Over here… help me…” Ross’s pulse skyrockets. The crate’s hum recedes into static. The only sound is her thudding heart. She raises her lamp toward the darkness and steps into the unknown.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully delivers on the space western premise with a tense, action-oriented sequence that follows the escape of the mysterious creature from its crate. The writing effectively builds suspense through environmental details and the crew's reactions to the unfolding crisis. The author demonstrates skill in creating a lived-in world through sensory details like "oil-dark fluid pools," "tobacco-stained sweat," and the "keening wail" of the crate. The ship feels like a real environment with its catwalk, grated floor, and emergency lighting systems. These details help ground the science fiction elements in tangible reality.
